[[File:Thyroid system.svg|thumb|200px|right|Short overview of thyroid homeostasis.<ref>References used in overview figure are found in image article in Commons: [[:File:Thyroid system.png#References|References]].</ref>]]
The '''hypothalamic–pituitary–thyroid axis''' ('''HPT axis''' for short, a.k.a. thyroid homeostasis or thyrotropic feedback control) is part of the [[neuroendocrine system]] responsible for the regulation of [[metabolism]].
As its name suggests, it depends upon the [[hypothalamus]], the [[pituitary gland]], and the [[thyroid gland]].
The hypothalamus senses low circulating levels of thyroid hormone (Triiodothyronine (T3) and Thyroxine (T4)) and responds by releasing thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH). The TRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to produce thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). The TSH, in turn, stimulates the thyroid to produce thyroid hormone until levels in the blood return to normal. Thyroid hormone exerts negative feedback control over the hypothalamus as well as anterior pituitary, thus controlling the release of both TRH from hypothalamus and TSH from anterior pituitary gland.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dietrich JW, Landgrafe G, Fotiadou EH|title=TSH and Thyrotropic Agonists: Key Actors in Thyroid Homeostasis|year=2012|journal=Journal of Thyroid Research|volume=2012|pages=1–29|doi=10.1155/2012/351864|pmc=3544290|pmid=23365787}}</ref>
The [[hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis|HPA]], [[hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis|HPG]], and HPT axes are three pathways in which the hypothalamus and pituitary direct neuroendocrine function.
==Physiology== [[File:Thyrotropic feedback control.svg|thumb|200px|left|Thyrotropic feedback control on a more detailed and quantitative level.<ref>References used in detailed figure are found in image article in Commons: [[:File:Thyrotropic feedback control.svg#References|References]].</ref>]] Thyroid homeostasis results from a multi-loop [[Feedback circuit|feedback system]] that is found in virtually all [[higher vertebrates]]. Proper function of thyrotropic feedback control is indispensable for [[Human development (biology)|growth]], [[Cellular differentiation|differentiation]], [[reproduction]] and [[intelligence]]. Very few animals (e.g. [[axolotl]]s and [[sloth]]s) have impaired thyroid homeostasis that exhibits a very low [[Setpoint (control system)|set-point]] that is assumed to underlie the [[Metabolism|metabolic]] and [[ontogenesis|ontogenetic]] anomalies of these animals.
The pituitary gland secretes [[thyrotropin]] (TSH; Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) that stimulates the thyroid to secrete [[thyroxine]] (T4) and, to a lesser degree, [[triiodothyronine]] (T3). The major portion of T3, however, is produced in peripheral organs, e.g. [[liver]], [[adipose tissue]], [[glia]] and [[skeletal muscle]] by [[deiodination]] from circulating T4. Deiodination is controlled by numerous [[hormone]]s and [[Nervous system|nerval signals]] including TSH, [[vasopressin]] and [[catecholamines]].
Both peripheral thyroid hormones ([[iodothyronine]]s) inhibit thyrotropin secretion from the pituitary ([[negative feedback]]). Consequently, equilibrium concentrations for all hormones are attained.
TSH secretion is also controlled by [[thyrotropin releasing hormone]] (thyroliberin, TRH), whose secretion itself is again suppressed by plasma T4 and T3 in [[cerebrospinal fluid|CSF]] ([[long feedback]], Fekete–Lechan loop).<ref name=LechanFekete2004>{{cite journal|last=Lechan|first=Ronald M.|author2=Fekete, C|title=Feedback regulation of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH): mechanisms for the non-thyroidal illness syndrome|journal=[[Journal of Endocrinological Investigation]]|year=2004|volume=27|issue=6 Suppl|pages=105–19|pmid=15481810}}</ref> Additional feedback loops are [[ultrashort feedback|ultrashort feedback control]] of TSH secretion (Brokken-Wiersinga-Prummel loop)<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Prummel MF, Brokken LJ, Wiersinga WM |doi=10.1089/thy.2004.14.825|pmid=15588378|title=Ultra short-loop feedback control of thyrotropin secretion|year=2004|journal=Thyroid|volume=14|issue=10|pages=825–9}}</ref> and [[linear feedback|linear feedback loops]] controlling [[plasma protein]] binding.
Recent research suggested the existence of an additional feedforward motif linking TSH release to deiodinase activity in humans.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Hoermann R, Midgley JE, Giacobino A, Eckl WA, Wahl HG, Dietrich JW, Larisch R |doi=10.1111/cen.12527|pmid=24953754|title=Homeostatic equilibria between free thyroid hormones and pituitary thyrotropin are modulated by various influences including age, body mass index and treatment|year=2014|journal=Clinical Endocrinology|volume=81|issue=6|pages=907–15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dietrich|first1=JW|last2=Midgley|first2=JE|last3=Larisch|first3=R|last4=Hoermann|first4=R|title=Of rats and men: thyroid homeostasis in rodents and human beings.|journal=The Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology|date=December 2015|volume=3|issue=12|pages=932–933|doi=10.1016/S2213-8587(15)00421-0|pmid=26590684}}<!--|accessdate=24 November 2015--></ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoermann|first1=R|last2=Midgley|first2=JE|last3=Larisch|first3=R|last4=Dietrich|first4=JW|title=Homeostatic Control of the Thyroid-Pituitary Axis: Perspectives for Diagnosis and Treatment.|journal=Frontiers in Endocrinology|date=2015|volume=6|pages=177|doi=10.3389/fendo.2015.00177|pmid=26635726|pmc=4653296}}<!--|accessdate=21 December 2015--></ref> The existence of this TSH-T3 shunt could explain why [[Sum activity of peripheral deiodinases|deiodinase activity]] is higher in hypothyroid patients and why a minor fraction of affected individuals may benefit from substitution therapy with T3.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Hoermann R, Midgley JE, Larisch R, Dietrich JW |doi=10.1055/s-0034-1398616|pmid=25750078|title=Integration of Peripheral and Glandular Regulation of Triiodothyronine Production by Thyrotropin in Untreated and Thyroxine-Treated Subjects|year=2015|journal=Hormone and Metabolic Research|volume=47|issue=9|pages=674–80}}</ref>
Convergence of multiple afferent signals in the control of TSH release including but not limited to T3,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoermann|first1=R|last2=Midgley|first2=JEM|last3=Dietrich|first3=JW|last4=Larisch|first4=R|title=Dual control of pituitary thyroid stimulating hormone secretion by thyroxine and triiodothyronine in athyreotic patients.|journal=Therapeutic Advances in Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=June 2017|volume=8|issue=6|pages=83–95|doi=10.1177/2042018817716401|pmid=28794850|pmc=5524252}}</ref> cytokines<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fliers|first1=E|last2=Kalsbeek|first2=A|last3=Boelen|first3=A|title=Beyond the fixed setpoint of the hypothalamus-pituitary-thyroid axis.|journal=European Journal of Endocrinology|date=November 2014|volume=171|issue=5|pages=R197–208|doi=10.1530/EJE-14-0285|pmid=25005935}}</ref><ref name="Chatzitomaris_2017"/> and TSH receptor antibodies<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Brokken LJ, Wiersinga WM, Prummel MF |doi=10.1210/jc.2003-030430|pmid=12970276|title=Thyrotropin receptor autoantibodies are associated with continued thyrotropin suppression in treated euthyroid Graves' disease patients|year=2003|journal=Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism|volume=88|issue=9|pages=4135–4138}}</ref> may be the reason for the observation that the relation between free T4 concentration and TSH levels deviates<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Hoermann R, Eckl W, Hoermann C, Larisch R |doi= 10.1530/EJE-10-0106|pmid=20299491|title=Complex relationship between free thyroxine and TSH in the regulation of thyroid function|year=2010|journal=[[European Journal of Endocrinology]]|volume=162|issue=6|pages=1123–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Clark PM, Holder RL, Haque SM, Hobbs FD, Roberts LM, Franklyn JA |doi= 10.1136/jclinpath-2011-200433|pmid=22287691|title=The relationship between serum TSH and free T4 in older people|year=2012|journal=Journal of Clinical Pathology|volume=65|issue=5|pages=463–5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Hoermann R, Midgley JE, Larisch R, Dietrich JW |doi= 10.1530/EJE-12-0819|pmid=23184912|title=Is pituitary TSH an adequate measure of thyroid hormone-controlled homoeostasis during thyroxine treatment?|year=2012|journal=European Journal of Endocrinology|volume=168|issue=2|pages=271–80}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Midgley JE, Hoermann R, Larisch R, Dietrich JW |doi=10.1136/jclinpath-2012-201213|pmid=23423518|title=Physiological states and functional relation between thyrotropin and free thyroxine in thyroid health and disease: In vivo and in silico data suggest a hierarchical model|year=2013|journal=Journal of Clinical Pathology|volume=66|issue=4|pages=335–42}}</ref> from a pure loglinear relation that has previously been proposed.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Reichlin S, Utiger RD |pmid=4163614|year=1967|title=Regulation of the pituitary-thyroid axis in man: Relationship of TSH concentration to concentration of free and total thyroxine in plasma|volume=27|issue=2|pages=251–5|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|doi=10.1210/jcem-27-2-251}}</ref>
==Functional states of thyrotropic feedback control== *[[Euthyroid]]ism: Normal thyroid function *[[Hypothyroidism]]: Reduced thyroid function **primary hypothyroidism: Feedback loop interrupted by low thyroid secretory capacity, e.g. after thyroid surgery or in case of [[autoimmune thyroiditis]] **secondary hypothyroidism: Feedback loop interrupted on the level of pituitary, e.g. in anterior pituitary failure **tertiary hypothyroidism: Lacking stimulation by TRH, e.g. in hypothalamic failure, [[Pickardt-Fahlbusch-Syndrome|Pickardt–Fahlbusch syndrome]] or [[euthyroid sick syndrome]]. *[[Hyperthyroidism]]: Inappropriately increased thyroid function **primary hyperthyroidism: Inappropriate secretion of thyroid hormones, e.g. in case of [[Graves' disease]]. **secondary hyperthyroidism: Rare condition, e.g. in case of TSH producing [[pituitary adenoma]] or partial thyroid hormone resistance. *[[Thyrotoxicosis]]: Over-supply with thyroid hormones, e.g. by overdosed exogenously levothyroxine supplementation. *[[Low t3 syndrome|Low-T3 syndrome]] and [[high t3 syndrome|high-T3 syndrome]]: Consequences of step-up [[hypodeiodination]], e.g. in [[critical illness]] as an example for type 1 [[allostasis]],<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Liu S, Ren J, Zhao Y, Han G, Hong Z, Yan D, Chen J, Gu G, Wang G, Wang X, Fan C, Li J |pmid=22874844|year=2013|title=Nonthyroidal illness syndrome: Is it far away from Crohn's disease?|volume=47|issue=2|pages=153–9|doi=10.1097/MCG.0b013e318254ea8a|journal=Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology}}</ref> or [[hyperdeiodination]], as in type 2 [[allostasis]], including [[posttraumatic stress disorder]].<ref name = "Chatzitomaris_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Chatzitomaris|first1=Apostolos|last2=Hoermann|first2=Rudolf|last3=Midgley|first3=John E.|last4=Hering|first4=Steffen|last5=Urban|first5=Aline|last6=Dietrich|first6=Barbara|last7=Abood|first7=Assjana|last8=Klein|first8=Harald H.|last9=Dietrich|first9=Johannes W.|title=Thyroid Allostasis–Adaptive Responses of Thyrotropic Feedback Control to Conditions of Strain, Stress, and Developmental Programming|journal=Frontiers in Endocrinology|date=20 July 2017|volume=8|pages=163|pmid=28775711|pmc=5517413|doi=10.3389/fendo.2017.00163}}</ref> *[[Thyroid hormone resistance|Resistance to thyroid hormone]]: Feedback loop interrupted on the level of pituitary thyroid hormone receptors.
==Diagnostics== Standard procedures cover the determination of [[Blood serum|serum]] levels of the following hormones: *[[Thyroid-stimulating hormone|TSH]] (thyrotropin, thyroid stimulating hormone) *[[Free thyroxine|Free T4]] *[[Free Triiodothyronine|Free T3]]
For special conditions the following [[assay]]s and procedures may be required: *Total T4 *Total T3 *[[Thyroxine-binding globulin|TBG]] *[[TRH test]] *[[Thyroid's secretory capacity|Thyroid's secretory capacity (GT)]]<ref name=dietrich2002>{{Cite book |publisher = Logos-Verlag Berlin |isbn = 978-3-89722-850-4 |location = Berlin, Germany |title = Der Hypophysen-Schilddrüsen-Regelkreis |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL24586469M/Der_Hypophysen-Schilddrüsen-Regelkreis |author = Dietrich, J. W. |date = 2002 |oclc = 50451543 |id = 3897228505 }}</ref> *[[Sum activity of peripheral deiodinases|Sum activity of peripheral deiodinases (GD)]]<ref name=dietrich2002/> *[[Thyroid function tests#TSH index|TSH Index (TSHI)]]<ref name=jostel2009>{{cite journal|vauthors=Jostel A, Ryder WD, Shalet SM |pmid=19226261|year=2009|title=The use of thyroid function tests in the diagnosis of hypopituitarism: Definition and evaluation of the TSH Index|volume=71|issue=4|pages=529–34|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2265.2009.03534.x|journal=Clinical Endocrinology}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Plot|date=November 2011}} }} {{italic title}} '''''Last Day of the Dinosaurs''''' is a 2010 [[Discovery Channel]] television documentary about the extinction of the dinosaurs. It portrays the [[Alvarez hypothesis]] as the cause of extinction. The documentary was released on August 28, 2010 and narrated by [[Bill Mondy]].
==Production== The dinosaur models created for ''[[Clash of the Dinosaurs]]'' were reused for this program. The ''[[Parasaurolophus]]'' model was used for ''[[Charonosaurus]]'' even though the legs of ''Charonosaurus'' were shorter than those of ''Parasaurolophus''. The ''[[Deinonychus]]'' model was used for ''[[Saurornithoides]]'' (rather inaccurately, as ''Saurornithoides'' was slenderer than ''Deinonychus''), and the ''[[Sauroposeidon]]'' model was used for ''[[Alamosaurus]]'' (even though ''Alamosaurus'' had different proportions than ''Sauroposeidon''). The same ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]'', ''[[Triceratops]]'', ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'', and ''[[Quetzalcoatlus]]'' models were also used. These models were placed upon different backdrops most of the time than those used in ''Clash of the Dinosaurs''.
==Plot== In the [[Pacific Northwest]] of [[North America]], a ''[[Quetzalcoatlus]]'' is soaring above the valley during a rainstorm when it spots an unguarded ''[[Tyrannosaurus Rex]]'' nest. The pterosaur flies down and consumes several of the hatchlings. Meanwhile, the father ''Tyrannosaurus'' is hunting for prey in the forest when his acute sense of smell alerts him to the intruder at the nest and runs back towards the nest. The ''Quetzalcoatlus'' is forced to flee when the enraged father ''Tyrannosaurus'' arrives, trying to fly off but its huge wings prevent it from flying in the thick forest. The ''T. rex'' repeatedly lunges and tries to kill it. It finally takes off just as the father ''T. rex'' bites the pterosaur's foot, though the pterosaur manages to break free of his jaws by pecking at his eye. Only one ''T. rex'' hatchling survives the carnage.
After a ''T. rex'' attacks an ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'' before being driven off, a male ''[[Triceratops]]'' loses a fight for mating rights against another male ''Triceratops''. Two ''T.rex'' hear the commotion and close in to hunt the loser. Working together, they bring down the ''Triceratops''. In [[Mongolia]] a herd of ''Charonosaurus'' is drinking at a watering hole in an [[oasis]]. A ''[[Saurornithoides]]'' steals an egg from a nest and flees, but the enraged mother follows the raptor into a cave. It tries to eat the egg, but the mother arrives, bellowing before the raptor's partner appears, and the ''Charonosaurus'' flees, with the ''Saurornithoides'' pair racing after it. They manage to bring down the ''Charonosaurus'' by tearing into its neck.
Meanwhile, in what is today central [[Mexico]], a herd of ''[[Alamosaurus]]'' is roaming the plains in search of food while a female lays her eggs without nesting, as a six-mile wide asteroid formed from the collision of two asteroids 100 million years earlier enters the [[Earth|Earth's]] atmosphere. The asteroid hits the Earth in the [[Gulf of Mexico]], creating a massive explosion and sending debris into the air. The explosion heats the air temperature near the crash site to 600° [[Fahrenheit|F]]. Hundreds of ''Alamosaurus'' are burned alive. Two minutes after impact, seismic shock waves trigger an 11.1 earthquake, which, combined with a second heat wave from the impact, wipes out the remaining ''Alamosaurus''. Most of their eggs are destroyed but some survive, buried under the cool soil.
The effects of the collision begin to affect the animals in British Columbia, with the 11.1 magnitude earthquake rippling through the valley. Falling debris litters the ground and drive animals from the valley. Several ''Triceratops'' and ''Ankylosaurus'' are engulfed by a 300° ejecta cloud and burnt to death. Fifteen minutes after impact, the ejecta cloud has spread to the Pacific Northwest and threatens to in-circulate the entire planet in ash. A pair of ''Quetzalcoatlus'' tries to fly away, but pieces of flaming debris shower the valley. Suffering from burnt wings, the male pterosaur falls from the sky to his death. After trying to save her mate, the also wounded female is forced to land in the valley. The effects of the ejecta also caused lightning storms to strike the valley.
The soaring temperatures create high humidity in the valley and force the ''Triceratops'' to keep moving. Many of the dead dinosaurs provide plentiful food for the hungry ''Tyrannosaurus''. The debris create massive fires that devastate forests of the Pacific Northwest. In the valley, the air pressure plummets, creating a vacuum that sucks in the raging flames and ignites a firestorm, causing temperatures in the valley to reaches 1800° F. The female ''Quetzalcoatlus'' stands over her mate's body but panics when the vegetation around her ignites. She manages to take off despite her tattered wings, leaving the dead male behind. Smaller animals hide underground while the larger animals are forced to flee.
In Mongolia, forty-five minutes since the impact, the ejecta cloud rolls in from the east, increasing the temperature around Mongolia by several degrees every second until it reaches 300°, causing three ''Charonosaurus'' and a pair of ''Saurornithoides'' to use a cave for shelter (unenthusiastically with each other as well). The temperatures return to normal after five hours, and the ''Saurornithoides'' run outside to feast on a ''Charonosaurus'' corpse, while two of the surviving ''Charonosaurus'' travel to the watering hole. The third stays behind. Soon the ejecta cloud causes a sandstorm, suffocating the two ''Charonosaurus'' alive. The pair of ''Saurornithoides'' survive by hiding behind their prey, while the third ''Charonosaurus'' remains in the cave. A day passes, and the ''Saurornithoides'' return to the watering hole, where the last ''Charonosaurus'' is drinking. The ''Saurornithoides'' are desperately hungry, yet are weak from their ordeal. One of them recklessly attacks the ''Charonosaurus'', but the hadrosaur collapses on top of it, killing it in the process. The remaining ''Saurornithoides'' resorts to eating the corpse of its companion.
Four days since impact, food is in short supply across the entire planet. In the Pacific Northwest, four ''Triceratops'' head towards an island in search of food. The earthquake caused by the impact event forms a huge [[megatsunami]], but also causes the water to recede and form a land bridge to the island. Three of the ''Triceratops'' cross the land bridge to the island. The female ''Quetzalcoatlus'' lands, where she eats a stranded fish, just as the megatsunami builds and races towards the shore. The ''Quetzalcoatlus'' attempts to take off but is caught into the vast wave and drowns, with the wave subsequently drowning the three ''Triceratops'' as well.
Ten days have passed since impact, and few dinosaurs remain. In Mongolia, the ''Charonosaurus'' stays close to the watering hole, but collapses and dies from inhaling [[hydrogen sulfide]] that rose from the watering hole. The ''Saurornithoides'' runs up to the dead ''Charonosaurus'', but it too is killed by the poisonous gas.
A month and a half later, in the Pacific Northwest, a handful of dinosaurs patrol the wasteland. A starving but weak ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'' finds a small bush, but it’s almost forced to fight over it when a wandering ''Triceratops'' appears, until the ''Tyrannosaurus'' arrives. The ''Tyrannosaurus'' loses an eye to his prey's horn, but he manages to break off one of its horns and kills it by simply lunging and biting down hard on the neck. The ''Tyrannosaurus'' then turns his attention to the ''Ankylosaurus'' and after being struck in the right leg, flips it over and rips out its throat. He heads back to the dead ''Triceratops'', but trips over the ''Ankylosaurus'' and is impaled through the neck on the ''Triceratops's'' remaining horn. In Mexico, an ''Alamosaurus'' baby emerges from an egg that was sheltered away in the ground. All around the world, small handfuls of dinosaurs try to start over, but their species are beyond hope for replenishing their numbers. In the end, inbreeding, disease, and starvation will wipe out their populations until a single ''Alamosaurus'' remains, only to die in the wasteland too, and it only took 160 million years to bring the dinosaurs to this catastrophic point in their evolution.
But life on Earth was not completely destroyed: fish and crocodiles surviving underwater; small mammals, snakes, insects, arachnids, and lizards hid underground; birds flew or swam away from the disaster. Three years pass before sunlight finally reaches the planet again, and plant life finally carpets the Earth again, setting the stage for a new era: the era of mammals. Mammals now multiply and diversify, with countless species of mammals evolving, until 10,000 species explode across the planet and one species, [[humans]], eventually rule the planet like the dinosaurs once had.

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Dakar Rally fatal accidents''' involving both competitors and non-competitors who have died during a [[Dakar Rally]] [[rally raid|event]].
Since 1979, 70 people are known to have died as a result of the Dakar rally. Among the 28 competitor fatalities, 19 were motorcycle related, 6 car related, 1 truck related, and 2 competitors died as a result of local rebel conflict. Up to 1992, collision was the most common cause of death among competitors.
Among the 42 non-competitor fatalities are those of the race's founder Thierry Sabine, 14 news journalists and support crew, 23 spectators, and 4 children.
The Dakar Rally has received criticism because of its high mortality rates, with the Vatican Paper describing the event as "the bloody race of irresponsibility".<ref>{{cite news|title=Danger Is Part of Race's Allure|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/27/sports/othersports/27autos.html|last=Bernstein|first=Viv|publisher=New York Times|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2015-01-18}}</ref> The event received particular criticism in the 1988 race, when three Africans were killed in collisions with vehicles involved in the race. [[Panafrican News Agency|PANA]], a Dakar-based news agency, wrote that the deaths were "insignificant for the [race's] organizers".<ref>{{cite news|title=Dangerous Paris-Dakar Race Is Endangered|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/13/world/dangerous-paris-dakar-race-is-endangered.html|last=Brooke|first=James|publisher=New York Times|date=1988-03-13|accessdate=2014-11-27}}</ref> The Dakar organizers have not officially recorded or reported on African and Latin American spectator and innocent bystanders deaths.<ref name="telegraph09dakar"/> As a result, fatality numbers for the Dakar vary from source to source, and bystander victims usually remain unnamed.
==List of fatal accidents involving competitors== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%;" |- ! No ! Name ! Date ! Place ! Stage ! Vehicle ! Type |- | 1 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Patrice Dodin | January [[1979 Paris–Dakar Rally|1979]] | [[Agadez]], [[Niger]] | [[Agadez]]—[[Tahoua]] | [[Yamaha XT 500]] | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Dodin, a French expatriate in Africa, lost control of his Yamaha while adjusting his helmet and fell approaching the start of the stage Agadez-Tahoua, hitting his head on a stone, sustaining a skull fracture. He was transferred to a hospital in Paris where he later died.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=1017 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dakar.com/98fr/20ans/1979.html |title=20 ans de Dakar |publisher=Dakar.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2003/01/11/motor/1042316515.html |title=Cauvy engrosa la lista de fallecidos en el Dakar - Motor |publisher=Elmundo.es |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref name="repub21mort">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2005/a/motori/gennaio05/21mortidakar/21mortidakar.html |title=/ Automobile: Tutte le vittime della Dakar Una lunga scia di sangue |publisher=Repubblica.it |date=2005-01-11 |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Sébastien LOURSEAU |url=http://www.dakardantan.com/paris-dakar-1979/dodin,yamaha+500+xt,78.html |title=Patrice DODIN - YAMAHA 500 XT n°78 - Paris Dakar 1979 |publisher=Dakardantan.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 2 | {{Flagicon|NED}} Bert Oosterhuis | January 7, 1982 | Ecker, [[Algeria]] | [[Quatre Chemins]]—[[Tit, Algeria|Tit]] | Yamaha XT 570 | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Oosterhuis, former road racing champion in the Netherlands, was killed between Bordj Omar Driss and [[Tit, Algeria|Tit]] in Algeria. He was 41 years of age.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3621 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dakar.com/98us/20ans/1982.html |title=20 ans de Dakar |publisher=Dakar.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 3 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Jean-Noël Pineau | January 14, 1983 | [[Léo, Burkina Faso|Léo]], [[French Upper Volta|Haute Volta]] | [[In-Gall]]—[[Korhogo]] | Yamaha XT 550 | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|In his fourth rally, Team Yamaha-France rider Pineau was killed a section of tarmac near [[Léo, Burkina Faso|Léo]] when he collided with a military vehicle. His best finish was 3rd overall.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=4985 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 4 | {{Flagicon|JPN}} Yasuo Kaneko | January 2, 1986 | [[Sète]], France | [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]—-[[Sète]] | [[Honda XR series#XR 500 .2F XR 500R|Honda XR 500]] | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|In his second start in the Dakar Rally, a non-entrant [[Peugeot 205]] crashed against the motorcycle of Keneko at 1:30 a.m. of Thursday, 2 January 1986, about 8 km before the harbour of [[Sète]], killing him instantly. The unnamed driver of the car was believed to have [[driving under the influence|driven under the influence of alcohol]]. He was 41 years of age.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3622 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 5 | {{Flagicon|ITA}} Giampaolo Marinoni | January 24, 1986 | [[Dakar]], [[Senegal]] | [[Saint-Louis, Senegal|Saint Louis]]—[[Dakar]] | [[Cagiva]] Elefant 650 | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Marinoni, a test rider of production motorcycles for [[Cagiva]] and in his second rally, fell within 40 km from the finish line at the final stage of the rally. He managed to reach the finish line in thirteenth place amongst 131 starters and 29 finishers of riders. Initially Marinoni did not feel that one of the brake levers of his Lucky Explorer-Cagiva had hurt his liver during the fall. He later arrived to be treated for his injuries in a hospital in Dakar, he succumbed to an infection two days later.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3623 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 6 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Jean-Claude Huger | January 17, 1988 | [[Nampalari]] | [[Timbuktu|Tombouctou]]—[[Bamako]] | [[BMW GS|BMW R 100 GS]] | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Huger was an escort rider for the President of the Republic of France and motorcyclist of the Gendarmerie Nationale. He crashed his BMW RT100 into a ditch near Nampala and hit his head on a rock, sustaining [[Head injury|cranial trauma]] and lapsing into a coma. He was airlifted to Paris where he died two days later without regaining consciousness.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3624 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref name="si020188"/><ref name="autevodakar"/> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 7 | {{Flagicon|NED}} Kees van Loevezijn | January 9, 1988 | [[Djado Plateau|Djado]], [[Niger]] | [[Djado Plateau|Djado]]—[[Agadez]] | DAF FAV3600 95X2 | Truck |- | colspan="7"|Theo van de Rijt, driver, Kees van Loevezijn, engineer, and Chris Ross from Scotland, were in a factory-entered [[DAF Trucks|DAF]] which had won its class the previous year. They hit a sand dune at about 180 km/h at 20 km from the start of a 414-mile leg and somersaulted several times, destroying the truck. Van Loevezijn was thrown out of the truck and died instantly. Van de Rijt and Ross were taken to a hospital in Agadez and airlifted to the Netherlands where they recovered. DAF withdrew the team from the rally and later terminated all motor-sport activities, selling the trucks and spare parts to factory driver Jan De Rooy's team. De Rooy re-entered the rally in 2002, at the age of 58.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref name="si020188"/><ref name="autevodakar">{{cite web|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/dakar-rally-death-toll-3147.html |title=Dakar Rally Death Toll |publisher=autoevolution |date=2009-07-27 |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=5001 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 8 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Patrick Canado | January 9, 1988 | [[Arlit]], [[Niger]] | [[Djado Plateau|Djado]]—[[Agadez]] | [[Range Rover Classic|Range Rover]] | Automobile |- | colspan="7"|During the seventh stage Djado-Agadez of the rally, in a large desert road, the [[Range Rover]] of French team René Boubet and Patrick Canado and the [[Mercedes-Benz W460|Mercedes-Benz 280]] of Italian team Klaus Seppi and Ambrogio Azzuffi collided at full speed some 25 km from the start of Arlit. Boubet's car, as it had steering problems, suddenly swerved into the other car and rolled several times. Co-driver Canado was thrown out of the car and was killed instantly; Boubet was seriously injured.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref name="si020188"/><ref name="autevodakar"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=5133 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 9 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} François Picquot | January 3, 1991 | ?, [[Libya]] | [[Ghadames]]—Idri | [[Nissan Terrano]] | Automobile |- | colspan="7"|During the second stage of the rally, Jacques Houssat, at the wheel of a truck [[Perlini]] P105, crashed into the Nissan Patrol of Henri De Roissard and François Picquot. The latter sustained head injuries and broken pelvis; he was airlifted to a hospital in France, where he later succumbed to his injuries. Houssat was eventually the winner of the truck category.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=5127 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 10 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Charles Cabannes | January 13, 1991 | In Kadeouane, [[Mali]] | Tombouctou—[[Néma]] | Mercedes-Benz | Truck |- | colspan="7"|Cabannes, a [[Rally support truck|support truck]] driver for the [[Citroën]] factory team, was shot dead by rebels at the side of the road in the small village of In Kadeouane during the 8th stage of the rally. His co-driver Joël Guyomarc'h had a superficial wound. The killing was not claimed by any rebel organization in the following days but was believed to be related with the conflict between the [[Military of Mali|Malian army]] and [[Tuareg Rebellion (1990–1995)|Touareg rebels]]. Organisers cancelled the following two rounds on schedule and the Malian army escorted the competitors while passing through the country. After the incident, team Nissan-Spain withdrew from the race.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref name="autevodakar"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=5128 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref name="AFP010408"/> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- |rowspan=2| 11 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Laurent Le Bourgeois |rowspan=2| December 27, 1991 |rowspan=2| Sabha, [[Libya]] |rowspan=2| [[Sirte]]—Sabha |rowspan=2| [[Land Rover Defender]] |rowspan=2| Automobile |- | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Jean-Marie Sounillac |- | colspan="7"|Land Rover Defender of Laurent Le Bourgeois and Jean-Marie Sounillac was an assistance vehicle for [[Jean-Louis Schlesser]]'s prototype buggy "Le Duc de Bourgoigne". It overturned several times in the Libyan desert of Sabah just a few kilometers before the end of the fifth stage of the rally. The impact of the crash caused the roll-bar of the car to collapse and both the occupants were crushed and killed at the scene.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=5103 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 13 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} [[Gilles Lalay]] | January 7, 1992 | Lumonbo, [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] | Francaville—[[Pointe-Noire]] | Yamaha-Byrd YZE750T | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Two hours after the end of the Francaville-Pointe Noire stage in Congo, 1989 winner Lalay, who finished fourth on the stage, was en route to the bivouac, when he was struck head-on by a Toyota belonging to the medical-assistance of the event organisers TSO (Thierry Sabine Organization). Lalay was taken to hospital at Lumonbo, where he succumbed to his injuries some hours later.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3506 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 14 | {{Flagicon|BEL}} Michel Sansen | January 4, 1994 | [[Nouakchott]], [[Mauritania]] | [[Nouakchott]]—[[Dakar]] | BMW | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|During the 8th stage, Sansen on his fifth start of the rally, running at speed on asphalt, suddenly lost control over a strip of sand, causing him to fall off, killing himself instantly. His nephew Jean-Philippe Miglotte, on another BMW, later immediately withdrew from the event following his uncle's death.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team, info@motorsportmemorial.org |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=3620 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date=1994-01-04 |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19940106&id=1-QTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7AcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4515,3277161 |title=Alison estate sues helicopter company|publisher= Ocala Star-Banner|date=Jan 6, 1994|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 15 | {{Flagicon|FRA}} Laurent Gueguen | January 3, 1996 | Forum El Hassam, [[Morocco]] | El Hassan—[[Smara]] | Mercedes-Benz | Truck |- | colspan="7"|While attempting to complete the 5th stage, Gueguen, driving a Mercedes-Benz truck (support vehicle for the [[Citroën]] team), got caught up in a conflict between the [[Royal Moroccan Army|Moroccan army]] and the [[Polisario Front]] rebels. Following the stage, on a desert track some 400 meters from the signed path, the vehicle struck an abandoned Moroccan army [[land mine]], causing it to explode, overturn and burst into flames from the impact, killing him instantly. Gueguen's co-drivers, Pascal Laudenot and Vincent Bauden, were able to escape from the wreckage, while Gueguen, who was driving at the moment of the accident, was not as fortunate.<ref name="repub21mort"/><ref name="autevodakar"/><ref name="AFP010408">{{cite web|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jl1qS1x0-ZchO5O5JNWXBJwut-IQ|title=AFP: Dakar Rally chiefs refuse to sound death knell|author=(AFP) – Jan 4, He was immediately treated by the medical teams of the rally, who transferred him to the [[Military camp|bivouac]] in [[Zouérat]] by helicopter. During an emergency procedure, he had his spleen, part of the liver and one kidney removed. He was later transferred to the Clinique du Cap in Dakar, Senegal, but his condition continued to worsen. He was airlifted to a hospital in Alicante, Spain, where he was put on [[intensive care]] and died a few hours later, within three days of his accident.<ref name="telegraph09dakar"/><ref name="repub21mort"/><ref name="autevodakar"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Motorsport Memorial Team |url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ms&n=2209 |title=Motorsport Memorial |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> |- | colspan="7" style="background:#000;"| |- | 20 | {{Flagicon|ITA}} [[Fabrizio Meoni]] | January 11, 2005 | | [[Atar, Mauritania|Atâr]]—[[Kiffa]] | KTM 660R | Motorcycle |- | colspan="7"|Meoni, winner of the rally in 2001 and 2002, crashed a few minutes after the first checkpoint during the 11th stage rally, breaking his neck. By the time a medical helicopter arrived, they were unable to revive him; his cause of death was [[myocardial infarction|heart failure]].
As grieving riders were unable to continue racing the next day, organisers cancelled the twelfth stage for all motorcyclists out of respect of Meoni.

'''Margaret Hanmer''' (c. 1370 – c. 1420), sometimes known by her [[Welsh language|Welsh]] name of '''Marred ferch Dafydd''', was the wife of [[Owain Glyndŵr]]. Although some modern histories have accorded Margaret the title "Princess of Wales",Deborah Fisher, ''Princesses of Wales'' (University of Wales Press, 2005) there is no contemporary record that Margaret used either that title or her husband's earlier title of Prince of Powys. "[[Princess of Wales]]", an English honorific given to the wife of the English prince of Wales, was first used by [[Joan of Kent]]. Only one wife of a Welsh prince is known to have used the title: [[Eleanor de Montfort]], wife of [[Llywelyn ap Gruffudd]], the last Prince of Wales. == Early life and marriage == [[File:Sycharth motte.JPG|right|thumb|Sycharth from field, showing motte]] [[File:Sycharth.JPG|right|thumb|Sycharth, showing motte and moat]] Nothing is known of Margaret's early life, not even the precise date of her marriage. She was the daughter of Sir [[David Hanmer]] and his wife Angharad ferch Llywelyn Ddu, and was probably raised in a Welsh household. Her father taught Owain Glyndwr when the latter studied law; it is not known when Margaret married Owain, although it is thought that their wedding may have taken place in 1383 in the church of St Chad's in [[Hanmer, Wales|Hanmer]]. The number of children she bore, and the dates of their births, are likewise uncertain. The poet [[Iolo Goch]] praises Margaret and her generosity in his poem ''Llys Owain Glyndŵr yn Sycharth'', one of three he composed in Owain's honour. ''A gwraig orau o’r gwragedd,
''Gwyn fy myd o’i gwin a’i medd!
''Merch eglur llin marchoglyw,
''Urddol hael anional yw;
''A’i blant a ddeuant bob ddau,
''Nythaid teg o benaethau.'' And the best of wives,
Blessed am I in her wine and mead!
A fine lady of knightly line,
Most generous by nature;
Her children come in two by two,
A beautiful nest of chieftains. Margaret had three brothers, Gruffydd, Philip and John, all of whom supported Glyndŵr when he formally assumed his ancestral title of Prince of Powys in 1400.[http://wbo.llgc.org.uk/en/s-HANM-HAN-1388.html Welsh Biography Online] The Hamners were still with Owain when a Welsh parliament proclaimed the latter Prince of Wales at Machynlleth in 1404. Margaret's husband held estates at [[Sycharth]], [[Glyndyfrdwy]], and elsewhere in North Wales. According to Sir John E. Lloyd, Margaret bore her husband five sons and four or five daughters. One daughter, [[Catrin ferch Owain Glyndŵr|Catrin]], married [[Edmund Mortimer, son of the 3rd Earl|Edmund Mortimer]], son of [[Edmund Mortimer, 3rd Earl of March|the Earl of March]] and brother-in-law of the famous [[Henry Percy (Hotspur)|Harry Hotspur]], who had been taken prisoner at the battle of Bryn Glas in 1402; when forbidden by the King to exercise his right to ransom himself, Sir Edmund allied himself with Glyndŵr. Another daughter, [[Alys ferch Owain Glyndŵr|Alys]], married [[John Scudamore (landowner)|Sir John Scudamore]] of Monnington Straddle, Sheriff of Hereford and castellan of several royal border fortresses. A third daughter, Janet, married Sir John de Croft of Croft Castle in Herefordshire, while a fourth, Margaret, married Sir Richard Monnington of Monnington, also in Herefordshire.[[Owain Glyndŵr|Glyndŵr]]'s sons are given as [[Gruffudd ab Owain Glyndŵr|Gruffudd]], Madog, [[Maredudd ab Owain Glyndŵr|Maredudd]], Thomas, John, and David. Gruffudd and Maredudd were certainly Margaret's sons, but which of the remaining four were also hers remains unknown. == Rebellion== [[File:Harlech Castle - Cadw photograph.jpg|330px|left|thumb|Harlech Castle]] [[File:SDJ Harlech Castle Gatehouse.jpg|right|thumb|Harlech Castle gatehouse]] After Owain proclaimed himself Prince of Powys on 16 September 1400, Margaret and her children were obliged to move to more secure accommodation to avoid capture by the English and becoming pawns, prisoners, informants and victims of the ruthless regime of the times. After their homes at Sycharth and Glyndyfrdwy were burned in 1403, they lived, among other places, at [[Harlech Castle]], which was taken in 1409 by the young [[Henry V of England|Henry of Monmouth]]. Upon the fall of Harlech, Margaret was captured and imprisoned in the Tower of London with her daughter [[Catrin ferch Owain Glyndŵr|Catrin]], another daughter, and Catrin's three daughters. Margaret's oldest son, [[Gruffudd ab Owain Glyndŵr|Gruffudd]], died in the Tower in 1411. Margaret survived the deaths of her two daughters and three granddaughters, but her own death is unrecorded. She is known to have been survived by her son [[Maredudd ab Owain Glyndŵr|Maredudd]], who was alive in 1421, and by her daughter [[Alys ferch Owain Glyndŵr|Alys]], Lady Scudamore, of Monnington Straddle. ==See also== *[[List of unsolved deaths]] ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= '''Margaret Hanmer''' |2= [[David Hanmer|Sir David Hanmer]] |3= Angharad ferch Llywelyn |4= Philip Hanmer (b. 1305) |5= Nest (Agnes) ferch Dafydd ap Rhirid |6= Llywelyn Ddu ap Gruffydd of [[Bryncunallt]] |7=Marred ferch Madog Fychan |8= John Hanmer (1277-1309) |9= Hawis ferch Einion ap Gruffydd |10= Dafydd ap Rhirid |11=Gwynhwyfar ferch Ednyfed |12= Gruffydd ab Iorwerth Foel |13= |14= Madog Fychan |15= Gwladus ferch Gruffudd ab Iorwerth |16= Sir Thomas de Macclesfield of Hamner |17= |18= Einion ap Gruffydd ap Gwenwynwyn of Powys |19= |20= Rhirid ab Ynyr ab Ionas |21= |22= Ednyfed ab Iorwerth |23= |24= Iorwerth Foel of Pengwern |25= Gwerful ferch Maredudd of Cantref Mechain |26= |27= |28= |29= |30= Gruffudd ab Iorwerth of Aberbury |31= Marred ferch Rhys Ieuanc }} ==Family connections== {{Glyndwr, the Hanmers and the Mortimers}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hanmer, Margaret}} [[Category:1370 births]] [[Category:1420 deaths]] [[Category:14th-century Welsh people]] [[Category:14th-century Welsh women]] [[Category:15th-century Welsh people]] [[Category:15th-century Welsh women]] [[Category:House of Mathrafal]] [[Category:Missing person cases in England]] [[Category:Unsolved deaths]] [[Category:Welsh princesses]]

'''Holly Lynn Bobo''' (October 12, 1990 – c. April 13, 2011) was an [[United States|American]] woman who disappeared on April 13, 2011, from her family home in [[Darden, Tennessee|Darden]], [[Tennessee]]. Bobo was last seen alive by her brother, Clint, shortly before 8 a.m., walking into the woods outside her home with a man wearing [[camouflage]]. In September 2014, partial remains were found in northern [[Decatur County, Tennessee|Decatur County]], and her death was ruled a [[homicide]] via a gunshot to the back of the head. Bobo was the cousin of singer [[Whitney Duncan]].<ref name=found>{{cite news|last1=Bule|first1=Jordan|title=Breaking: TBI says remains found are Holly Bobo|url=http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/special-reports/abduction-holly-bobo/2014/09/08/tbi-breaking-news/15316959/ |newspaper=[[The Jackson Sun]] |date=September 8, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Searles">{{cite news|last1=Searles|first1=Kaylin|title=State: Indentation on Holly Bobo's skull consistent with bullet hole|url=http://fox17.com/news/local/state-identation-on-holly-bobos-skull-consistent-with-bullet-hole|accessdate=August 9, 2017|work=Fox 17, Nashville|date=August 9, 2017}}</ref>
Six men have been arrested for varying degrees of involvement in the crime. However, only three of the six have been [[prosecution|prosecuted]].<ref name="austin arrest">{{cite news|last1=Gaines|first1=Charley|title=Two more men arrested in connection with Holly Bobo case|url=http://www.waaytv.com/appnews/two-more-men-arrested-in-connection-with-holly-bobo-case/article_7b6cfd84-f10a-11e3-9457-001a4bcf6878.html|work=ABC 21|date=June 10, 2014}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Most of the arrests were made on the basis of a [[confession]] by a man with an [[intellectual disability]] named John Dylan Adams, who told police he saw his brother, Zach, and another friend, Jason Autry, with Holly at his brother's home after her [[kidnapping]]. It is unknown what led police to question Dylan about Bobo's disappearance.<ref name="innocence">{{cite news|title=Holly Bobo Case: Jason Autry, Zach Adams State Innocence During Arraignment|url=http://fox17.com/fox_17_this_morning/features/bobo/stories/holly-bobo-case-jason-autry-zach-adams-state-innocence-during-arraignment-16.shtml|work=[[Fox News]]|access-date=July 31, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808050633/http://fox17.com/fox_17_this_morning/features/bobo/stories/holly-bobo-case-jason-autry-zach-adams-state-innocence-during-arraignment-16.shtml|archive-date=August 8, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Dylan, Zach, and Autry were charged with especially aggravated kidnapping, [[first-degree murder]] and [[rape]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = State plans to seek death penalty against 3 suspects in Holly Bobo case|url = http://www.wfsb.com/story/29210663/suspects-in-holly-bobo-case-to-appear-in-court-wednesday#.VW8YDfU4UkA.mailto |accessdate=June 3, 2015 |first = Stuart|last = Ervin}}</ref> Of the other three men arrested, charges against two men were dropped, and one committed suicide without any charges being filed against him.
The case has been met with several setbacks such as the death of a suspect, multiple changes to the prosecutorial team, and disputes with the [[Tennessee Bureau of Investigation]] (TBI). The prosecution has been heavily criticized for its refusal to produce evidence against the defendants, missing multiple discovery deadlines, and for making frequent changes to the charges against the defendants with little explanation. The TBI even briefly withdrew its services to the entire district after the prosecutor accused it of compromising the case by proceeding "so slowly that the culprits were always one step ahead and that TBI... was leaking information and possibly covering up evidence."<ref name="fall out">{{cite news|last1=Conte|first1=Chris|title=Emails Reveal New Details In Heated Holly Bobo Fallout|url=http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Emails-Reveal-New-Details-in-Heated-Holly-Bobo-Fallout-290992851.html|work=News Channel 5|date=February 2, 2015|access-date=March 14, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311030212/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Emails-Reveal-New-Details-in-Heated-Holly-Bobo-Fallout-290992851.html|archive-date=March 11, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[Defense attorney]]s for the men said they still had yet to receive a [[bill of particulars]] detailing the case against their clients and the results of forensic testing done on evidence from the case over a year after the arrests were made, and filed motions to dismiss charges on the grounds of "silence or stonewalling."<ref name="Evidence" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=Strange New Twist In The Holly Bobo Case|url=http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Strange-New-Twist-In-The-Holly-Bobo-Case-287550941.html|work=News Channel 5|date=January 5, 2015|access-date=January 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107084340/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Strange-New-Twist-In-The-Holly-Bobo-Case-287550941.html|archive-date=January 7, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Apel|first1=Kara|title=Judge frustrated with how slowly Bobo suspects' cases are moving|url=http://www.wsmv.com/story/27650560/suspects-in-holly-bobo-case-appear-in-court|work=WSMV|date=December 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Faris|first1=Maranda|title=Bobo murder suspects could face death if convicted|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/06/03/holly-bobo-death-penalty-sought/28442435/ |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> The arrests took place in early 2014, but it wasn't until July 2015 that it was announced that the defendants finally received access to all the evidence against them.<ref name="evidence"/><ref name="no dna">{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=Zach Adams' Attorney Discusses Plea Deals, DNA In Bobo Case|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/zach-adams-attorney-discusses-plea-deals-dna-in-bobo-case|work=News channel 5|date=February 2, 2017|access-date=February 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204085507/http://www.newschannel5.com/news/zach-adams-attorney-discusses-plea-deals-dna-in-bobo-case|archive-date=February 4, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
On September 22, 2017, a jury found Zach guilty on all charges, including first-degree murder.<ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite news|title=Holly Bobo trial: Defendant found guilty of murder, kidnapping and rape|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/09/22/holly-bobo-trial-defendant-zach-adams-found-guilty-first-degree-murder-aggravated-kidnapping-and-agg/695086001/ |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=September 22, 2017}}</ref> He was sentenced to [[life imprisonment|life in prison]] plus 50 years on September 23. He maintains his innocence.<ref name="parole">{{cite news|last1=WKRN web staff|title=Life in prison without parole + 50 years for Zach Adams, convicted in murder of Holly Bobo|url=http://wkrn.com/2017/09/23/jury-set-to-begin-penalty-phase-for-zachary-adams/|work=[[WKRN]] |date=September 23, 2017}}</ref> In January 2018, Zach's brother, Dylan, accepted an [[Alford plea]] and he was sentenced to 35 years in prison.<ref name="alford">{{cite news|last1=Yusuf|first1=Omer|title=Holly Bobo trial: John Dylan Adams gets 35 years|url=http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/special-reports/abduction-holly-bobo/2018/01/22/holly-bobo-no-plea-deal-yet-john-dylan-adams/1053455001/|agency=The Jackson Sun|date=January 22, 2018}}</ref>
==History== At the time of her disappearance, Holly Bobo was a 20-year-old [[nursing]] student in the [[Licensed Practical Nurse]] program at the [[University of Tennessee]] at Martin Parsons Center in [[Parsons, Tennessee|Parsons]], living with her parents and brother in [[Darden, Tennessee|Darden]]. Friends described her as shy and sweet. She was the cousin of [[Country music|country singer]] [[Whitney Duncan]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/04/18/tennessee.missing.woman/|title=Reward soars 200% in Tennessee nursing student's disappearance|last=|first=|date=|newspaper= |accessdate=February 10, 2017|work=CNN|via=}}</ref> In 2017, Duncan released a song called "Better Place" in memory of Holly.<ref name="better place">{{cite news|last1=Bado|first1=Kirk|title=Nashville singer releases song remembering cousin Holly Bobo|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2017/07/13/nashville-singer-releases-song-remembering-cousin-holly-bobo/475451001/ |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=July 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Disappearance== A timeline of events on the morning of April 13, 2011, is given below, on the basis of witness statements and reported phone records: * '''4:30 a.m.''' Holly awoke to study for an exam.<ref name=Timeline/> * '''7:30 a.m.''' Holly answered a call from her boyfriend, Drew Scott, who was [[turkey hunting]] nearby on her grandmother's property. Holly's parents had left for work by this point and her brother Clint was still asleep.<ref name=Timeline/><ref name=Bule>{{cite news|last1=Bule|first1=Jordan|title=Final hours with Holly: Family, friends, police reconstruct time before Holly Bobo's abduction|url=http://archive.jacksonsun.com/article/20120101/NEWS25/102200007/Final-hours-Holly-Family-friends-police-reconstruct-time-before-Holly-Bobo-s-abduction|newspaper=[[The Jackson Sun]]|date=October 8, 2011|access-date=July 31, 2014|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806052914/http://archive.jacksonsun.com/article/20120101/NEWS25/102200007/Final-hours-Holly-Family-friends-police-reconstruct-time-before-Holly-Bobo-s-abduction|archive-date=August 6, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * '''7:42 a.m.''' Holly made her last cell phone call. After this point, all phone calls and texts were incoming and unanswered.<ref name="Faris">{{cite news|last1=Faris|first1=Maranda|title=Holly Bobo trial- Day 6: Witnesses support Autry, Dinsmore accounts|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/special-reports/abduction-holly-bobo/2017/09/15/holly-bobo-trial-day-6-what-know-saturday/668692001/ |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=September 15, 2017}}</ref> At some point after this call ended, a neighbor heard a scream from the Bobo residence.<ref name=Timeline/><ref name=KHPO/> * '''7:46 a.m.''' The neighbor called his mother to tell her about the scream, who called Karen Bobo at work.<ref name=Timeline>{{cite news|last1=Manna|first1=Nicole|title=A fresh look at the Holly Bobo case|url=http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/special-reports/abduction-holly-bobo/2014/09/06/fresh-look-at-holly-bobo-case/15225381/ |newspaper=[[The Jackson Sun]] |date=September 6, 2014}}</ref><ref name=KHPO/> * '''7:50 a.m.''' Clint was awakened by the family dogs barking and saw a man with Holly outside. "It appeared to be Holly kneeling down and Drew [Scott]. They looked like they were kneeled down, facing each other in the garage, and they were talking back and forth. Holly sounded very upset and heated. He was doing much of the talking, and she would answer back and things like that. I couldn't make out hardly any of the words. The only words I could make out from here were Holly saying, 'No, why?{{'"}} Clint said that he believed the couple were breaking up. At some point, Karen called home and spoke to Clint. "I said, 'Clint, that's not Drew. Get a gun and shoot him.{{'"}} Clint reportedly replied, "You want me to shoot Drew?", still believing the man was Holly's boyfriend.<ref name=Timeline/><ref name=KHPO/> * '''7:55 a.m.''' Karen called [[9-1-1]], but because she was calling from work she reached the dispatcher for the wrong county. At home, Clint looked outside again and saw the man dressed in [[camouflage]] walking with Holly into the woods. At this point, he noted that the man with Holly was larger than Drew Scott.<ref name=KHPO>{{cite news|last1=Ferrier|first1=Dennis|title=Holly Bobo's brother tells his side of the story for the first time|url=http://www.kpho.com/story/22123465/holly-bobos-brother-tells-his-side-of-the-story |work=[[KHPO]] |date=April 30, 2013}}</ref> He tried to call Holly's cell phone as well as Scott's cell phone, but neither call was answered.<ref name=Timeline/> * '''8:00 a.m.''' Karen called her house again. Clint told her what he saw and she instructed him to call 9-1-1. Clint got a loaded pistol and went outside, where he found bloodstains belonging to Holly in the carport, then dialed 9-1-1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1108/04/ijvm.01.html|title=Issues with Jane Velez-Mitchell|last=Velez-Mitchell|first=Jane|date=August 4, 2011|work=|accessdate=January 9, 2017|via=}}</ref><ref name="Timeline" /><ref name="Corbin">{{cite news|last1=Corbin|first1=Cristina|title=Holly Bobo's mother breaks down on stand as disturbing details emerge in murder trial|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/09/12/holly-bobo-murder-trial-officials-describe-finding-suspicious-mattress-scratches-on-alleged-killer.html |work=[[Fox News]] |date=September 12, 2017}}</ref> * '''8:10 a.m.''' Police began to arrive at the Bobo residence.<ref name=Timeline/> * '''8:17 a.m.''' Cell phone pings showed Holly's cell phone moving away from her home tower heading north.<ref name="Chapman">{{cite news|last1=Chapman|first1=Bridget|title=Holly Bobo Trial, day 6: Cell phone records tie Autry and Adams to area where Bobo was shot|url=http://wreg.com/2017/09/16/holly-bobo-trial-day-6-saturday-scheduled-to-be-a-short-day/ |work=[[WREG-TV|WREG Memphis]] |date=September 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name="cell records">{{cite news|last1=WKRN staff|title=Defense rests case in Zach Adams' trial after testimony on Bobo's cell phone|url=http://wkrn.com/2017/09/20/defense-continues-to-call-witnesses-in-holly-bobo-trial/ |work=[[WKRN]] |date=September 20, 2017}}</ref> Her cell phone continued north to a wooded area near [[Interstate 40 in Tennessee|Interstate 40]], where her remains were eventually found.<ref name="20/20">{{cite news|title=20/20: Justice For Holly|url=http://abc.go.com/shows/2020/episode-guide/2017-09/29-092917-justice-for-holly|agency=20/20|date=September 29, 2017}}</ref> *'''8:30–9:00 a.m.''' The cell phone stopped moving for 20–30 minutes. The cell phone then began traveling south again using a different route.<ref name="20/20"/> * '''9:25 a.m.''' The last cell phone ping came from Holly's phone in the area where her phone and its [[SIM card]] were later found.<ref name="Faris"/>
==Investigation== Clint described the man as being between 5′10″ and 6 feet tall (1.78–1.80 m), weighing {{convert|180|-|200|lb}} and having dark hair sticking out from under his cap that was long enough to cover his neck and touch his collar. Clint said the man was wearing a hat and camouflage clothing from head to toe and identified the pattern as either [[Mossy Oak]] break up or leafy wear. He described the male voice he heard as a very deep and low.<ref name="height and weight">{{cite news|title=Man was waiting for Holly Bobo: Crime expert|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/man-was-waiting-for-holly-bobo-crime-expert/ |work=[[CBS News]] |date=April 16, 2011}}</ref>
Extensive searches of the area were conducted following Bobo's disappearance. Several items belonging to Bobo were found scattered throughout the town, including her lunchbox, a receipt with her name on it, a card from school, her cell phone, and the SIM card, which had been removed from it.<ref name="personal items">{{cite news|last1=Action News Staff|title=DNA, personal items entered as evidence in Holly Bobo murder trial|url=http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36354420/bobo-trial-day-3-more-key-witnesses-expected-to-take-stand |work=Action News 5 |date=September 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="lunchbox">{{cite news|title=Searchers find missing Holly Bobo's lunchbox|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1377604/Searchers-missing-Holly-Bobos-lunchbox.html|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=April 16, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Evidence">{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tKv3ETdo3_4|title=Evidence Linking Bobo Murder Suspects To The Crime|date=May 18, 2015|work=News Channel 5 |accessdate=January 9, 2017|via=|last1=Beres|first1=Nick}}</ref>
Early in the investigation, the [[Tennessee Bureau of Investigation]] (TBI) focused heavily on a registered [[sex offender]] who matched the witness description named Terry Britt.<ref name="Britt">{{cite news|last1=Chamberlain|first1=Samuel|title=Holly Bobo trial: Defense blames 'Chester the Molester' for killing|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/09/19/holly-bobo-trial-defense-blames-chester-molester-for-killing.html |work=[[Fox News]] |date=September 20, 2017}}</ref> His home was wire-tapped and searched during the course of the investigation, but he was never charged.<ref name="Britt history"/><ref name="Britt search">{{cite news|last1=Searles|first1=Kaylin|title=Holly Bobo trial: State rests its case after suspect's former jailmates take the stand|url=http://fox17.com/news/local/holly-bobo-trial-state-rests-its-case-after-suspects-former-jailmates-take-the-stand |work=Fox News 17|date=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2014, Bobo's partial remains were found by [[ginseng]] hunters in a wooded area of northern [[Decatur County, Tennessee]], just off of I-40, nearly 20 miles (32 km) from Darden.<ref name="i40">{{cite news|last1=Crimesider Staff|title=Remains found in Tenn. county where Holly Bobo disappeared|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/remains-found-in-county-where-tennessee-nursing-student-holly-bobo-disappeared/|agency=48 hours crimesider|date=September 8, 2014}}</ref><ref name=found/><ref name="Conte">{{Cite news|url = http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Man-Who-Found-Holly-Bobo-It-Will-Be-With-Me-Forever-274824611.html|title = Man who found Holly Bobo: It will be with me forever|last = Conte|first = Chris|date = September 11, 2014|work = News Channel 5|accessdate = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140913114311/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Man-Who-Found-Holly-Bobo-It-Will-Be-With-Me-Forever-274824611.html|archive-date = September 13, 2014|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> The owner of the property said it was not uncommon for people to hunt there without permission.<ref name="remains found">{{cite news|title=Property owner where Holly Bobo remains found speaks|url=http://www.fox17.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/only-fox-property-owner-holly-bobo-remains-found-speaksmikayla-lewis-23423.shtml|work=[[WZTV|WZTV Fox 17]]|date=September 10, 2014|access-date=September 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912030720/http://www.fox17.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/only-fox-property-owner-holly-bobo-remains-found-speaksmikayla-lewis-23423.shtml|archive-date=September 12, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> One of the men who found the remains said he saw a large bucket in the woods, which he upturned. Details of the contents have not been released. He then spotted Bobo's remains spread on the ground behind him.<ref name="Conte"/><ref name="Found Holly">{{cite news|last1=Conte|first1=Chris|title=Man who found Holly Bobo: We want Justice for Holly|url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/Man-Who-Found-Holly-Bobo-We-Want-Justice-For-Holly-301450711.html|work=News Channel 5|date=April 27, 2015|access-date=May 19, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150501124140/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/Man-Who-Found-Holly-Bobo-We-Want-Justice-For-Holly-301450711.html|archive-date=May 1, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Investigators recovered her skull, teeth, several ribs, and one shoulder blade.<ref name="remains">{{cite news|last1=Hardaway|first1=Brittany|title=Experts examine remains in Holly Bobo murder trial|url=http://www.wbbjtv.com/2017/09/13/warning-graphic-photos-experts-examine-remains-holly-bobo-murder-trial/|work=WBBJ 7 Eyewitness News|date=September 13, 2017}}</ref> Her skull had a bullet hole in the back of it on the right with the trajectory going left, fracturing her left [[Zygomatic bone|cheek bone]] when it exited.<ref name="skull">{{cite news|last1=News Channel 5 Staff|title=Jurors See Items Found Near Holly Bobo's Remains|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/bobo/bobo-trial-to-resume-after-damaging-testimony |work=News Channel 5|date=September 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Arrests== A total of six men have been implicated in connection with Bobo's disappearance, with the first of the arrests occurring in March 2014, prior to the discovery of Holly's remains. Zach Adams, his brother Dylan Adams, and friend Jason Autry were ultimately charged with especially aggravated kidnapping, first-degree murder, and rape.<ref name="Hearing date">{{cite news|last1=Faris|first1=Maranda|title=Defendants in Bobo case face death penalty if convicted|url=http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/crime/2015/06/03/defendants-in-bobo-case-face-death-penalty-if-convicted/28405251/ |newspaper=[[The Jackson Sun]] |date=June 3, 2015}}</ref> Another two men, Jeffrey and Mark Pearcy, were arrested on charges of [[Accessory (legal term)|accessory after the fact]] and [[tampering with evidence]]; however charges against the Pearcy brothers were dropped. Another man, Shayne Austin, committed suicide.<ref name="crimesider"/>
It is unclear what initially led law enforcement to suspect these men, but the investigation began with the arrest of Dylan Adams on unrelated weapons charges. Following this arrest, he told police that he witnessed Bobo alive with his brother at Zach's home following her abduction.<ref name=WKRN>{{cite news|last1=Pleasant|first1=Joseph|title=Zachary Adams tried to threaten brother, report says|url=http://www.wkrn.com/story/25132232/tbi-files-new-charge-against-zachary-adams |work=[[WKRN]] |date=April 1, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Fox News">{{cite news|title=Witnesses saw suspects with Holly Bobo, After kidnapping, TBI says|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/04/30/witnesses-saw-suspects-with-holly-bobo-after-kidnapping-tbi-says/ |work=[[Fox News]] |date=April 30, 2014}}</ref><ref name=beres/> An affidavit for a search warrant states that Dylan told authorities that on April 13, 2011, he went to Zach's residence to get his truck. Dylan reportedly "observed Holly Lynn Bobo sitting in a green chair in the living room wearing a pink t-shirt, with Jason Wayne Autry standing just a few feet away." He also told police Zach was "wearing camouflage shorts, black cut-off-sleeve t-shirt and a pair of green Crocs" shoes. Dylan also said that Zach told him "he had raped Bobo and videotaped it." The alleged videotape has not been found.<ref name="Evidence"/><ref name="Fox News" /><ref name="beres" /> Dylan later recanted the confession and alleged that he was coerced, but his confession led to the arrests of Zach Adams, Jason Autry, and Shayne Austin. Many of the details contained in the confession were eventually found to be inconsistent with the known evidence, and the narrative presented later in court was vastly different. In early 2017, it was announced that Jason Autry had agreed to testify against Zach in exchange for leniency.<ref name="autry immunity">{{cite news|last1=WBBJ 7 Eyewitness News Staff|title=BREAKING: Jason Autry granted immunity in Holly Bobo case|url=http://www.wbbjtv.com/2017/07/07/breaking-jason-autry-granted-immunity-holly-bobo-case/ |work=WBBJ 7 Eyewitness News |date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>
In 2014, District Attorney Matt Stowe said he and the [[Tennessee Bureau of Investigation|TBI]] were still "actively looking" to bring criminal charges against additional people, although he declined to name the parties or the charges.<ref name="Timeline" />
