===Jeff and Mark Pearcy=== In July 2014, Jeffrey Pearcy and his brother Mark Pearcy were arrested and charged with [[Accessory (legal term)|accessory after the fact]] and tampering with evidence. They were arrested on the basis of allegations made by Jeff's former roommate Sandra King, who alleged that in May 2014, Jeff showed her part of a video showing Adams assaulting Bobo, who was tied up and crying. She told police that she watched only a small clip and did not see the sexual assault. Police arranged for King to make a recorded call to Jeff where she told him over the phone "That video of Holly, if it had been you, I would have watched it," to which he replied, "I know." King alleges that Pearcy's brother Mark shot the video.
Both brothers deny that a video existed and Jeff Pearcy denies knowing the other men who have been arrested for the crime.<ref name=Gordon/> Jeff claims that he was unable to hear Sandra during the phone conversation and that his ex-wife's name is also Holly. Police have analyzed over 20 phones but have not found any video.<ref name=Manna/> Charges against both men were subsequently dropped and the narrative described at Zach Adams's trial did not include any mention of involvement by the Pearcy brothers.<ref name="Manna">{{cite news|last1=Manna|first1=Nichole|title=Witness says she saw Holly Bobo tied up on video|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/crime/2014/07/29/witness-says-she-saw-holly-bobo-tied-up-in-video/13330099/ |work=[[The Tennessean]]|date=July 29, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = DA Not Pursuing Charges Against Suspect In Bobo Case At This Time|url = http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/Officials-Not-Pursuing-Charges-Against-Suspect-In-Bobo-Case-280863742.html|accessdate = June 5, 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150609023917/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/Officials-Not-Pursuing-Charges-Against-Suspect-In-Bobo-Case-280863742.html|archive-date = June 9, 2015|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref>
==Trial of Zach Adams== In September 2017, Zach Adams was the first to go on trial. The prosecution's case was largely circumstantial, as there was no DNA or other forensic evidence tying Zach to the murder.<ref name="DNA">{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=Is There Enough Evidence To Convict Zach Adams In Murder Of Holly Bobo?|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/is-there-enough-evidence-to-convict-zach-adams-in-murder-of-holly-bobo |work=News Channel 5 |date=February 27, 2017}}</ref> Jason Autry, the state's key witness, testified to a series of events that was drastically different from Dylan's confession. He testified that he himself was not involved in the abduction but that he went to Shayne Austin's home to buy drugs where he saw Zach, Dylan, and Shayne disposing of evidence from the crime.<ref name="key witness">{{cite news|last1=Cruz|first1=Rachel|title=Holly Bobo Murder Trial Update 2017: Key Witness Jason Autry Could Be Lying|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/holly-bobo-murder-trial-update-2017-key-witness-jason-autry-could-be-lying-192018/ |work=Christian Post|date=July 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Autry narrative"/> He said Zach had a body in the back of his truck wrapped up in a multi-colored blanket and Shayne was disposing of evidence in a burn barrel.<ref name="Autry narrative">{{cite news|last1=Truesdell|first1=Jeff|title='I Need You to Help Bury This Body': Witness Says He Acted as Lookout When Friend Shot Nursing Student Holly Bobo|url=http://people.com/crime/holly-bobo-trial-jason-autry-testifies-against-zachary-adams/ |work=[[People Magazine]] |date=September 15, 2017}}</ref>
According to Jason Autry, he agreed to help Zach dispose of the body. They drove to a spot along the [[Tennessee River]] with plans to "gut" her so she didn't float to the top. After unloading her body from the bed of the truck, they realized she was still alive, so Zach shot her in the back of the head. Fearing that the noise of the gunshot might have attracted attention, they loaded her body back into the truck and Zach dropped Jason off.<ref name="Autry narrative"/> Autry testified that Zach later said that he'd dumped the body near a place called Kelly Ridge. (Her remains were found in a different location and it is unclear how the body ended up where it was ultimately found.)<ref name="Kelly ridge">{{cite news|last1=Hardaway|first1=Brittany|title=Jason Autry testifies in Holly Bobo murder trial entire day|url=http://www.wbbjtv.com/2017/09/14/jason-autry-testifies-holly-bobo-murder-trial-entire-day/ |work=WBBJ 7 Eyewitness News|date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
The narrative presented at trial is that Zach, Shayne, and Dylan went to the Bobo residence to teach Clint Bobo to make meth, an allegation that Clint denies.<ref name="Clint Meth">{{cite news|last1=Dooley|first1=Sean|last2=Effron|first2=Lauren|title=Holly Bobo's brother, who saw her being abducted, and parents recall day she vanished|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/holly-bobos-brother-person-alive-parents-recall-day/story?id=50131287 |work=ABC News|date=September 27, 2017}}</ref> Holly came out of the home "screaming and hollering" and that is when the men abducted her.<ref name="make meth">{{cite news|last1=News Channel 5 Staff|title=7 Main Takeaways From Autry's Testimony In Bobo Murder Trial|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/7-main-takeaways-from-autrys-testimony-in-bobo-murder-trial |work=News Channel 5|date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> The prosecution alleged that Shayne Austin was the man that Clint described as walking into the woods with Holly, as he is the only one who was close to the size of the man he described.<ref name="crimesider">{{cite news|last1=Crimesider Staff|title=Holly Bobo case: Star witness testimony in dispute as case heads to jury|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/holly-bobo-case-star-witness-testimony-in-dispute-as-case-heads-to-jury-deliberations-continue/ |work=48 hours Crimesider |date=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The three men are alleged to have raped Holly in a local barn owned by the grandmother of both Shayne Austin and Jason Autry.<ref name="crimesider"/>
Two pieces of paper belonging to Holly, a receipt and a note card, were found on the road where Shayne Austin lived. The receipt was found 75 feet from Austin's driveway.<ref name="receipt">{{cite news|last1=Crimesider Staff|title=Agent admits investigators made mistakes in Holly Bobo case|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/agent-state-police-made-mistake-in-holly-bobo-case/ |work=48 hours crimesider |date=September 15, 2017}}</ref>
The prosecution also presented other pieces of circumstantial evidence linking Zach to the murder, including that he drove a white truck; a neighbor of the Bobo family had seen a white truck driving rapidly the morning of the murder.<ref name="Babb">{{cite news|last1=WMC Action News 5 Staff|title=Bobo Trial: Emotional day one testimony culminates with Holly's mother|url=http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36332827/holly-bobo-murder-trial-begins-monday|accessdate=September 24, 2017 |work=WMC Action News 5 |date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> A number of other witnesses testified that Zach made statements implicating himself in her disappearance. Zach's then-girlfriend, Rebecca Earp, testified that "He said he would tie me up just like he did Holly Bobo and nobody would ever see me again."<ref name="Earp">{{cite news|last1=WKRN web staff|title=Zach Adams' ex says she tried to leave him day before Bobo's disappearance|url=http://wkrn.com/2017/09/12/testimony-continues-in-holly-bobo-trial/|work=[[WKRN]] |date=September 12, 2017}}</ref> He also allegedly threatened Dylan after his arrest that he would "put him in a hole beside her" if he didn't keep his mouth shut.<ref name="hole">{{cite news|last1=Crimesider Staff|title=Inmate: Man charged with killing Tennessee woman Holly Bobo made threat|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/inmate-man-charged-with-killing-tennessee-woman-holly-bobo-made-threat/ |work=48 Hours Crimesider |date=September 18, 2017}}</ref>
A gun, listed as an Arminus model HW5, 32 caliber [[Smith & Wesson]] long [[revolver]] was introduced into evidence by the prosecution.<ref name="IBT">{{cite news|last1=VARANDANI|first1=SUMAN|title=Holly Bobo Murder Trial Update: Suspected Murder Weapon 'Crucial Piece Of Evidence', State Says|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/holly-bobo-murder-trial-update-suspected-murder-weapon-crucial-piece-evidence-state-2563979|accessdate=July 11, 2017 |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> A local man, Victor Dinsmore, led police to the gun, claiming that Shayne Austin and Jason Autry sold him the weapon in exchange for drugs. It was reportedly found under water.<ref name="gun water">{{cite news|last1=WMC Action News Staff|title=TBI never found Bobo's DNA at Zach Adams' home|url=http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36374031/bobo-trial-day-5-gruesome-details-shed-light-on-murder |work=WMC Action News 5 |date=September 15, 2017}}</ref> Forensic tests on the weapon failed to find any DNA or fingerprints on the weapon and prosecutors were unable to link the gun to the case with ballistics tests<ref name="gun">{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=New Developments Emerge Regarding Evidence In Holly Bobo Murder Case|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/local-news/new-developments-emerge-regarding-evidence-in-holly-bobo-murder-case |work=News Channel 5 |date=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
On September 22, 2017, a jury found Zach Adams guilty on all charges, including first-degree murder, especially aggravated kidnapping, and aggravated rape.<ref name="usatoday.com"/> On September 23, 2017, he was sentenced to life in prison without parole and two consecutive terms of 25 years for both the kidnapping and rape convictions.<ref name="parole"/>
==John Dylan Adams==
On January 18, 2018, John Dylan Adams pled guilty to charges of facilitation of first-degree murder and especially aggravated kidnapping. He was sentenced to 15 years for facilitation of first-degree murder and 35 years for especially aggravated kidnapping. Those sentences are set to run concurrently, meaning he will serve 35 years without parole. Dylan entered an [[Alford plea]], a type of guilty plea where the defendant does not admit to the criminal act and maintains his innocence but concedes that the prosecution's case may result in a guilty verdict.<ref name="alford"/>
==Innocence claims== Despite confessions from Autry, Austin, and Dylan Adams, all men arrested for the crime have vehemently denied involvement in the disappearance at some point and have accused the state of coercive tactics. Early in the case, Autry claimed that investigators tried to get him to testify falsely against Zach Adams.<ref name=beres>{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=Holly Bobo Murder Suspect Jason Autry Speaks Out About Case|url=http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/259872621.html|work=News channel 5|date=May 19, 2014|access-date=July 31, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912113736/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/259872621.html|archive-date=September 12, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The family of Dylan Adams, who is mentally disabled, claimed that "[T]hey kept him up all night, would not give him anything to eat or drink and finally he said, 'What do you want me to say?{{'"}}<ref name="allegation">{{Cite news|url = http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/special-reports/abduction-holly-bobo/2014/09/23/exclusive-family-member-says-dylan-adams-knowingly-disposed-evidence-holly-bobo-case/16128815/|title = Exclusive: Family member says Dylan Adams would not have knowingly disposed of evidence in Holly Bobo case|last = Bule|first = Jackson|date = September 24, 2014|newspaper = [[The Jackson Sun]]|accessdate= }}</ref> According to family members, Dylan has some ability to read but cannot perform other tasks such as telling time, and they believe that Dylan is being manipulated.<ref name="family speaks">{{cite news|title=Suspect's family Speaks|url=http://www.wsmv.com/video?clipId=10620607&autostart=true |work=[[WSMV-TV|WSMV]] |date=September 25, 2014}}</ref>
At the trial for Zach, it was alleged that the state used unethical investigatory techniques to coerce a confession from Dylan. In 2014, Dylan was arrested on federal gun charges that would have ended in a lengthy prison sentence. The prosecutor, who was also handling the Bobo case, arranged a no-jail plea deal on the condition that he go live with a retired police officer, Dennis Benjamin, whom Dylan did not know. Five weeks later, Benjamin called 911 to report that he had someone in his home that wanted to confess to the murder of Holly Bobo. Despite the fact that this confession led to the arrests, much of what he confessed to did not match the evidence.<ref name="Benjamin">{{cite news|last1=Editor|title=Holly Bobo: The Trial Day One – Beginning of the Journey's End|url=https://www.lexingtonprogress.com/2017/09/11/holly-bobo-the-trial-day-one-beginning-of-the-journeys-end/|accessdate=September 24, 2017 |work=The Lexington Progress |date=September 11, 2017}}</ref>
Dylan's mother claims that there was extensive coercion in his interrogation: "In this statement Dylan is trying to tell his story as to what happened, and you've got this TBI agent saying, 'Don't you mean this? Don't you mean it happened like this?' And, 'No, Dylan, it went down like this.' And you can honestly tell at [that] point that Dylan, I can as his mother, he gave up. He's like, 'OK, if that's what you said, OK,{{'"}} Cindy Adams said.<ref name="Mother">{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Carley|title=Mother of Holly Bobo murder suspects breaks her silence|url=http://www.wsmv.com/story/35435363/mother-of-holly-bobo-murder-suspects-breaks-her-silence |work=[[WSMV-TV|WSMV Nashville]] |date=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
Jeffrey Pearcy also claims the statements regarding his involvement were fabricated by King to assist her son, who has been in prison for 14 years and has 24 years left on his sentence.<ref name=Manna/> "I have been up front and honest about everything. I have willingly given them everything. Take it, I mean, it's there," he said. "My heart goes out to the Bobo family. It could have very well been one of my kids. For someone to give them false hope, and that's exactly what's been done to them," he said. "But for the justice system to just haul someone in and destroy their whole life, I mean, there's no sense in that at all."
===Zach Adams defense=== At Zach Adams's trial, his defense contended that he was "100% innocent."<ref name="100 percent">{{cite news|last1=WKRN Staff|url=http://wkrg.com/2017/09/22/zach-adams-found-guilty-on-all-charges-in-holly-bobo-murder-case/ |title=Zach Adams Found Guilty on All Charges in Holly Bobo Murder Case |accessdate=September 25, 2017|work=[[WKRG-TV|WKRG News 5]] |date=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The defense alleged that Jason Autry concocted a story in exchange for a reduced sentence and that although some of his story seemed to be corroborated he had access to all these details through discovery. They also pointed to the fact that cell phone pings do not follow the path that Holly's cell phone takes and that none of the men matched the witness description given by Clint Bobo. Zach, Dylan, and Jason were all too tall and were either too slim or too heavy to be the abductor. Shayne Austin was the correct weight and height, but Clint described a man with dark hair that covered his neck; Shayne had short red hair.<ref name="defense case">{{cite news|last1=Editor|title=Bobo Trial: Prosecution, Defense Present Closing Arguments|url=https://www.lexingtonprogress.com/2017/09/21/bobo-trial-closing-arguments/|accessdate=September 25, 2017 |work=The Lexington Progress |date=September 21, 2017}}</ref>
Former TBI agent Terry Dicus, who was the lead investigator on the case, testified for the defense. He told the jury that he ruled the men out early in the case because Shayne Austin passed a polygraph, their alibis checked out, and cell phone records put Zach and Holly several miles apart during the critical time frame.<ref name="20/20"/> According to a defense expert, Zach's and Holly's cell phones were in separate sectors nearly the entire time frame of her abduction; the cell phones came into the same sector only at about 9:10 a.m., over an hour later.<ref name="cell records">{{cite news|last1=Mojica|first1=Adrian|title=Holly Bobo Trial: Defense refocuses on Britt as possible killer, cell phone data|url=http://fox17.com/news/local/holly-bobo-trial-defense-refocuses-on-britt-as-possible-killer-cell-phone-data|agency=Fox 17|date=September 20, 2017}}</ref> Dicus also noted that for Autry's story to fit with the cell phone pings, they would have to drive 106 miles per hour, a scenario that is unlikely on the winding gravel roads they traveled.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Brett|title=Former defense witness claims Autry’s testimony wasn’t true in Bobo case|url=http://wkrn.com/2017/11/10/former-defense-witness-claims-autrys-testimony-wasnt-true-in-bobo-case/|agency=WKRN|date=November 10, 2017}}</ref> The defense also noted that all four men had been ruled out as the originator of a palmprint found on Holly's car, while another suspect, Terry Britt, could not be excluded.<ref name="palm print">{{cite news|last1=WMC Action News 5 Staff|title=Prosecutor: Holly Bobo deserves justice; jury resumes deliberations Friday|url=http://www.wave3.com/story/36418958/zach-adams-fate-on-the-line-as-closing-arguments-cap-murder-trial|agency=WMC Action News 5|date=September 21, 2017}}</ref>
===Terry Britt=== Zach's defense attorney, Jennifer Thompson, contends that the initial suspect in the case, Terry Britt, was the real killer, saying that he "has never been cleared by the TBI and in fact it appears the government has more evidence of his guilt than it does of the three defendants charged in the present case."<ref name="Gordon">{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Carley|title=Attorney: Possible new suspect in Holly Bobo case|url=http://www.fox19.com/story/32777404/attorney-possible-fourth-suspect-in-holly-bobo-case |work=Fox 19 Now |date=August 17, 2016}}</ref>
Britt is a convicted sex offender who has been convicted of three separate rapes and, {{as of|2017|lc=y}}, is serving time in prison for the 2008 kidnapping and attempted rape of another woman.<ref name="Britt search"/><ref name="Britt history">{{cite news|last1=WBIR Staff|title=State rests its case against Zach Adams in murder of Holly Bobo|url=http://www.wbir.com/news/crime/state-rests-its-case-against-zach-adams-in-murder-of-holly-bobo/476834476 |work=[[WBIR]] |date=September 18, 2017}}</ref> It was argued at trial that Britt fit the physical description and had a history of stalking blond women. Clint Bobo also identified a voice sample of Britt's voice as being very similar to the voice he heard that morning.<ref name="Britt hair"/>
Former TBI agent Terry Dicus testified that Britt had fabricated an alibi for that morning. Britt told investigators that his wife stayed home from work that morning to help him install a bathtub. Through the investigation, Dicus discovered that his wife, Janet, had gone to work that morning but Terry called and made her leave "on the biggest news day" of the county's history. The Britts did produce a handwritten receipt for the bathtub, but the store had no record of the sale. According to Dicus, Britt's wife had been with him on previous occasions where Britt had stalked girls. Britt also could not be excluded as the contributor of the handprint.<ref name="Dicus">{{cite news|last1=Mojica|first1=Adrian|title=Holly Bobo Trial: Former TBI agent explains focus on Terry Britt, not Zach Adams|url=http://fox17.com/news/local/holly-bobo-trial-former-tbi-agent-explains-focus-on-terry-britt-not-zach-adams |work=Fox 17 Nashville|date=September 19, 2017}}</ref> He also testified that following Holly's abduction, Terry Britt allegedly changed his appearance by cutting his hair.<ref name="Britt hair">{{cite news|last1=Chapman|first1=Bridget|last2=Taylor|first2=Eryn|title=Holly Bobo trial, day 8: Defense's turn to take center stage|url=http://wreg.com/2017/09/19/defenses-turn-to-take-center-stage-in-holly-bobo-murder-trial/ |work=News Channel 3 Memphis |date=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
A [[U.S. Marshals]] senior inspector testified that at one point, Britt said, "Sounds like you have it all figured out," and said he would "plead to it," but did not clarify specific charges or conditions for a plea deal.<ref name="britt plead">{{cite news|last1=Crimesider Staff|title=Marshals official says sex offender offered to make plea in Holly Bobo case|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/marshals-official-says-sex-offender-offered-to-make-plea-in-holly-bobo-case/ |work=48 Hours Crimsider |date=September 20, 2017}}</ref>
==Criticisms of the prosecution== The criminal case against the men charged has been met with strong criticism and conflict between members of the prosecution, complicating the investigation. District Attorney Matt Stowe was elected to office in the summer of 2014 following the arrests and stated that he believes he was elected in part due to skepticism regarding the arrests and questions over whether enough evidence exists against them to obtain a conviction. "[Voters] wanted another set of eyes on this Holly Bobo case; they weren't happy with everything that was coming out of there, and I think that they wanted someone else to take a look and someone else to say, 'We know what's going on.{{'"}}<ref name="Timeline" />
In the fall of 2014, Jason Autry's attorney, John Herbison, accused the prosecutor of arresting the defendants without probable cause as an unethical "investigatory technique," then adding and dropping charges strategically before hearings to avoid having to produce evidence against the defendants.<ref name="wsmv.com"/><ref name=found/><ref name="Timeline" /> In October 2014, when [[evidence tampering]] charges were dropped against Dylan Adams just days after he was charged with rape, Herbison said: "If those reports are correct, it means that they're just playing games," Herbison said. "They charged him with something less serious in order to keep him locked up, and then when it comes time to answer questions about the charge, they dismiss that and charge him with a more serious charge in circuit court, where he's not entitled to a preliminary hearing."<ref name="wsmv.com">{{Cite news|url = http://www.wsmv.com/story/26817760/autrys-attorney-weighs-in-on-changes-in-bobo-case|title = Autry's attorney weighs in on changes in Bobo case|last = Gordon|first = Carley|date = October 17, 2014|work = WSMV|accessdate = }}</ref>
He also noted the state's similar treatment of Mark Pearcy to avoid hearings. In August 2014, the state failed to arrange transport for Pearcy to the courthouse causing the hearing to be rescheduled for September, but just prior to the new hearing the charges against him were dropped with the explanation given that Pearcy was facing unrelated federal charges and they were being forced to wait to proceed with the state charges. Herbison said the laws regarding the charges would not preclude the state charges. "If the state is claiming that is the case, the prosecutor is either ill-informed or being disingenuous," he said. Charges were never reinstated and the case against his brother, Jeff, was similarly dropped.<ref name="wsmv.com"/><ref name="charges dropped">{{cite news|last1=Manna|first1=Nichole|title=Judge upset when Holly Bobo suspect is absent from court|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2014/08/19/judge-upset-holly-bobo-not-in-court/14276581/ |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=August 19, 2014}}</ref>
Zach Adams's attorney, Jennifer Thompson, repeatedly said that evidence wasn't turned over to the defense. For example, in 2014, DA Matt Stowe made a statement that because Holly was menstruating at the time of her abduction there was a lot of DNA evidence in Zachary Adams's Decatur County home. No DNA evidence was ever turned over to the defense or produced at trial. She also said that the medical examiner referred to materials that were never given to her.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Carley|title=Attorney: Possible new suspect in Holly Bobo Case|url=http://www.fox19.com/story/32777404/attorney-possible-fourth-suspect-in-holly-bobo-case |work=Fox 19 Now |date=August 17, 2016}}</ref>
On December 17, 2014, nine months after Zach Adams's arrest, Judge Creed McGinley chastised prosecutors for delays in the case and for the state's failure to turn over evidence to the defense. "I am absolutely out of patience with these cases not moving," he said. Judge McGinley ordered that a bill of particulars be filed for Zachary Adams's case within seven days and that discovery take place immediately. The prosecution ignored both deadlines.<ref name="Beres"/><ref name="Apel">{{cite news|last1=Apel|first1=Kara|title=Judge frustrated with how slowly Bobo suspects' cases are moving |url=http://www.wsmv.com/story/27650560/suspects-in-holly-bobo-case-appear-in-court |work=[[WSMV-TV|WSMV]] |date=December 17, 2014}}</ref> In response, attorneys for the men filed motions to dismiss charges.<ref name="Beres"/><ref name="Apel"/><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Holly-Bobo-Rape-Suspect-Demands-He-Be-Released-297575411.html|title = Holly Bobo rape suspect demands release from jail|last = Conte|first = Chris|date = March 25, 2015|work = News Channel 5|accessdate = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150328030804/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/news/Holly-Bobo-Rape-Suspect-Demands-He-Be-Released-297575411.html|archive-date = March 28, 2015|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> The motions filed accused the state of "silence or stonewalling," stating that, among other things, the state had yet to disclose evidence that the skull found belonged to Bobo. "It would appear to me if they had a skull with a dental match they would have given that to us right away. It's a little suspicious why we don't have that forensic information," said Autry's attorney Fletcher Long.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/suspects-holly-bobo-murder-case-judge-drop-charges-article-1.2063239|title = Suspects in Holly Bobo murder case ask judge to drop charges over lack of evidence|last = Associated Press|first = |date = January 1, 2015|work = New York Daily News|accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Evidence" /><ref name="evidence">{{cite news|last1=Beres|first1=Nick|title=Defense Attorneys Receive Full Access To Evidence In Holly Bobo Case|url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/FULL-DISCOVERY--READY-IN-BOBO-CASE-314684031.html|work=News channel 5|date=July 13, 2015|access-date=July 14, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714081737/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/newschannel5/news/FULL-DISCOVERY--READY-IN-BOBO-CASE-314684031.html|archive-date=July 14, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.wsmv.com/story/27773904/court-dates-postponed-special-prosecutor-named-in-holly-bobo-murder-case|title = Court dates postponed, special prosecutor named in Holly Bobo murder case|last = Gordon|first = Carley|date = January 6, 2015|work = WSMV|accessdate = }}</ref>
Following the hearing in December 2014, a dispute regarding the handling of the case led the TBI to briefly drop its investigation of the case and cut ties with the entire district, saying District Attorney Matt Stowe had accused them of misconduct. The TBI agreed to come back on the case after Stowe recused himself from the case and Jennifer Nichols was appointed as special prosecutor.<ref name="WMC">{{cite news|title=TBI severs ties with 24th Judicial District, suspends Holly Bobo murder investigation|url=http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/27655885/tbi-severs-ties-with-24th-judicial-district-suspends-holly-bobo-murder-investigation |work=WMC Action News 5 |date=December 17, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Walker">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Ken|title=Paris, TN: Stowe off Bobo case as TBI resumes operations in 24th Judicial District|url=http://www.parispi.net/news/local_news/article_5df19bea-873a-11e4-a1f2-2f256a977733.html |work=The Paris Post Intelligencer |date=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="channel 11">{{cite news|title=TBI back on the Holly Bobo case|url=http://www.wjhl.com/story/27668008/tbi-back-on-the-holly-bobo-case |work=News Channel 11 |date=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="WREG">{{cite news|last1=Crockett|first1=Ashley|title=Judge appoints special prosecutor in Holly Bobo case|url=http://wreg.com/2015/01/06/judge-appoints-special-prosecutor-in-holly-bobo-case/ |work=[[WREG-TV|WREG News Channel 3]] |date=January 6, 2015}}</ref> Following Stowe's allegations of misconduct by the TBI, the defense attorneys working on the case stated that they intended to subpoena Stowe to question him regarding the alleged misconduct.<ref name="Beres" /> Emails by Wally Kirby, Executive Director of Tennessee District Attorney's Conference, revealed that Stowe accused TBI of compromising the case by proceeding "so slowly that the culprits were always one step ahead and that TBI...was leaking information and possibly covering up evidence."<ref name="fall out"/><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/01/23/tennessee-investigative-agency-says-it-has-finished-evidence-analysis-in-holly/|title = Tennessee investigative agency says it has finished evidence analysis in Holly Bobo case|last = Associated Press|first = |date = January 23, 2015|work = Fox News|accessdate = }}</ref>
==Media coverage== The case attracted a high level of national media coverage.<ref name="Robin L. Barton">{{cite news|last=Barton|first=Robin L.|title=The "Missing White Woman Syndrome"|url=http://www.thecrimereport.org/viewpoints/robin-barton/2011-08-the-missing-white-woman-syndrome|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref> [[Discovery Channel]] published an article several months after her disappearance, discussing how the high levels of media coverage, including some instances of inaccurate media coverage, hurt the investigation. A notable example of misinformation was the description of her last known movements. Early reports inaccurately reported that Bobo was dragged into the woods. Clint later clarified that Holly had, in fact, walked with the man wearing [[camouflage]] into the woods, either willingly or by coercion. This clarification led to rumors that Clint had changed his story and was a suspect in his sister's disappearance. Whitney Duncan defended him in an April 17 Twitter statement, stating that he was innocent and not a suspect in the case.<ref name=Discovery/> Some early sources also erroneously reported that the skull was found on property owned by Zach Adams's family.<ref name="People">{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=k.c.|title=Third Man Indicted in Kidnapping, Rape and Murder of Tennessee Nursing Student Holly Bobo|url=http://people.com/crime/holly-bobo-murder-john-dylan-adams-indicted/ |work=[[People Magazine]] |date=May 22, 2015}}</ref> Her body was found 10 miles away from Adams's property on land owned by the Tubbs family.<ref name="Christie">{{cite news|last1=Christie|first1=Joel|title=Human skull found in woods 10 miles from the home of man charged with kidnapping and murdering nursing student Holly Bobo|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2747371/Human-skull-woods-10-miles-home-man-charged-kidnapping-murdering-nursing-student-Holly-Bobo.html |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=September 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Buie">{{cite news|last1=Buie|first1=Jordan|title=Property owner perplexed by discovery of human remains|url=http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/news/local/2014/09/08/property-owner-perplexed/15299615/ |work=[[The Jackson Sun]] |date=September 8, 2014}}</ref>
Police received scores of erroneous tips from the public, including a number of "[[psychics]]," making it difficult for police to identify important leads.<ref name=Discovery>{{cite news|last1=Radford|first1=Benjamin|title=Holly Bobo still missing: Rumors, psychics hurt search|url=http://news.discovery.com/human/holly-bobo-still-missing-rumors-psychics-hurt-search.htm |work=[[Discovery News]] |date=June 7, 2011}}</ref>
On Friday night September 29, 2017, the ABC network aired an investigative journalism segment, "Justice for Holly Bobo," on its prime-time television program 20/20.<ref>http://www.localmemphis.com/news/local-news/holly-bobo-case-focus-of-2020-friday-night-at-9pm-on-local-24/821387466</ref>

{{distinguish|Occupational burning}} {{Infobox disease |Name = Occupational burn-out |Synonyms = Burn-out |ICD10 = {{ICD10|Z|73|0|z|70}}, {{ICD10|F|43|8}} }} '''Occupational burnout''' is thought to result from long-term, unresolvable, job stress. In 1974, [[Herbert Freudenberger]] became the first researcher to publish in a ''psychology''-related journal a paper that used the term ''burnout''. The paper was based on his observations of the volunteer staff (including himself) at a free clinic for drug addicts.<ref name="staffburnout1">{{cite journal|author=Freudenberger, H.J.|year=1974|title=Staff burnout|journal=Journal of Social Issues|volume= 30|pages=159–165|doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1974.tb00706.x}}</ref> He characterized burnout by a set of symptoms that includes exhaustion resulting from work's excessive demands as well as physical symptoms such as headaches and sleeplessness, "quickness to anger" and closed thinking. He observed that the burned-out worker "looks, acts, and seems depressed". After the publication of Freudenberger's original paper, interest in occupational burnout grew. Because the phrase "burnt-out" was part of the title of a 1961 Graham Greene novel, ''A Burnt-Out Case'', which dealt with a doctor working in the Belgian Congo with patients who had leprosy, the phrase may have been in use outside the psychology literature before Freudenberger employed it.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Burnt-Out Case|last=Greene|first=Graham|publisher=William Heinemann Ltd|year=1961|isbn=978-0140185393|pages=cover title}}</ref>
In order to study burnout, a number of researchers developed more focused conceptualizations of burnout. In one conceptualization, job-related burnout is characterized by emotional exhaustion, depersonalization (treating clients/students and colleagues in a cynical way), and reduced feelings of work-related personal accomplishment.<ref name = "Maslach">{{cite journal|authors=Maslach, C., Jackson, S.E, & Leiter, M.P. |title=MBI: The Maslach Burnout Inventory: Manual|publisher= Consulting Psychologists Press|location=Palo Alto|year= 1996|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/277816643}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceD">{{cite journal|last1=Ruotsalainen|first1=JH|last2=Verbeek|first2=JH|last3=Mariné|first3=A|last4=Serra|first4=C|title=Preventing occupational stress in healthcare workers.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=7 April 2015|issue=4|pages=CD002892|pmid=25847433|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002892.pub5}}</ref> In another conceptualization, burnout is thought to comprise emotional exhaustion, physical fatigue, and cognitive weariness.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Shirom, A., & Melamed, S.|year=2006|title=A comparison of the construct validity of two burnout measures in two groups of professionals|journal=International Journal of Stress Management|volume=13|issue=2|pages=176–200|doi=10.1037/1072-5245.13.2.176}}</ref> A third conceptualization holds that burnout consists of exhaustion and disengagement.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Demerouti | first1 = E | last2 = Bakker | first2 = A.B. | last3 = Vardakou | first3 = I. | last4 = Kantas | first4 = A. | year = 2002 | title = The convergent validity of two burnout instruments: A multitrait-multimethod analysis | url = | journal = European Journal of Psychological Assessment | volume = 18 | issue = 1| pages = 296–307 | doi = 10.1037/a0037726 | pmid = 25151460 }}</ref> The core of the three conceptualizations, as well as Freudenberger's, is exhaustion. Long limited to these dimensions, burnout is now known to involve the full array of depressive symptoms (e.g., low mood, cognitive alterations, sleep disturbance).<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., Schonfeld, I.S., & Laurent, E.|year=2015|title=Burnout-depression overlap: A review|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=36|pages=28–41|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2015.01.004|pmid=25638755}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Schonfeld | first2 = I. S. | last3 = Vandel | first3 = P. | last4 = Laurent | first4 = E. | year = 2017 | title = On the depressive nature of the "burnout syndrome": A clarification | url = | journal = European Psychiatry | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 109–110 | doi = 10.1016/j.eurpsy.2016.10.008 | pmid = 28135592 }}</ref>
Originally, Maslach and her colleagues focused on burnout within human service professions (e.g., teachers, social workers).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jackson | first1 = S. | last2 = Schwab | first2 = R. | last3 = Schuler | first3 = R. | year = 1986 | title = Toward an understanding of the burnout phenomenon | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Psychology | volume = 71 | issue = 4| pages = 630–640 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.71.4.630}}</ref> She later expanded the application of burnout to include individuals in many other occupations.<ref name = "Maslach"/>
== Diagnosis == Burnout is not recognized as a distinct disorder in the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-5]].<ref name="sciammind2">{{cite web|author=Ulrich Kraft|publisher=Scientific American|title=Burned Out|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/burned-out/|date=June 2006|pages=28–33}}</ref> It is included in the [[ICD-10]], but not as a disorder.<ref>ICD-10: International Classification of Diseases. Geneva: World Health Organization, 2015.</ref> It can be found in the ICD under problems related to life-management difficulty (Z73).
In 1981, [[Christina Maslach]] and Susan Jackson developed the first widely used instrument for assessing burnout, namely, the [[Maslach Burnout Inventory]] (MBI).<ref name = "Maslach2">{{cite journal|authors=Maslach, C., & Jackson, S.E.|year=1981|title=The measurement of experienced burnout|journal=Journal of Occupational Behavior|volume= 2|issue=2|pages=99–113|doi=10.1002/job.4030020205}}</ref> Consistent with Maslach's conceptualization, the MBI operationalizes burnout as a three-dimensional syndrome consisting of emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and reduced personal accomplishment.<ref name = "Maslach2"/><ref name = "Maslach"/> Other researchers have argued that burnout should be limited to fatigue and exhaustion.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Kristensen|first1 = T.S.|last2 = Borritz|first2 = M.|last3 = Villadsen|first3 = E.|last4 = Christensen|first4 = K.B.|year = 2005|title = The Copenhagen Burnout Inventory: A new tool for the assessment of burnout|url = |journal = Work & Stress|volume = 19|issue = 3|pages = 192–207|doi = 10.1080/02678370500297720}}</ref>
A growing body of evidence suggests that burnout is etiologically, clinically, and [[nosology|nosologically]] similar to [[Major depressive disorder|depression]].<ref>Bianchi, E., Schonfeld, I.S., & Laurent, E. (2018). Burnout syndrome and depression. Y.-K. Kim (Ed.), ''Understanding depression: Volume 2. Clinical manifestations, diagnosis and treatment'' (pp.187-202). Singapore: Springer. doi:10.1007/978-981-10-6577-4_14</ref><ref name = "Ahola">{{cite journal | last1 = Ahola | first1 = K. | last2 = Hakanen | first2 = J. | last3 = Perhoniemi | first3 = R. | last4 = Mutanen | first4 = P. | year = 2014 | title = Relationship between burnout and depressive symptoms: A study using the person-centred approach | url = | journal = Burnout Research | volume = 1 | issue = 1| pages = 29–37 | doi=10.1016/j.burn.2014.03.003}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., & Laurent, E. |year=2015|title=Emotional information processing in depression and burnout: An eye-tracking study|journal=European Archives of Psychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience|volume=265|issue=1|pages=27–34|doi=10.1007/s00406-014-0549-x|pmid=25297694}}</ref><ref name="Bianchi, R. 2014">{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Schonfeld | first2 = I. S. | last3 = Laurent | first3 = E. | year = 2014 | title = Is burnout a depressive disorder? A re-examination with special focus on atypical depression | url = | journal = International Journal of Stress Management | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 307–324 | doi=10.1037/a0037906}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., Schonfeld, I. S., & Laurent, E. |title= Is burnout separable from depression in cluster analysis? A longitudinal study|journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology|volume=50|issue= 6|pages= 1005–1111|doi=10.1007/s00127-014-0996-8|pmid= 25527209|year=2014}}</ref><ref name="Hintsa-et-al">{{cite journal|authors=Hintsa, T., Elovainio, M., Jokela, M., Ahola, K., Virtanen, M., & Pirkola, S. |year=2016|title=Is there an independent association between burnout and increased allostatic load? Testing the contribution of psychological distress and depression|journal=Journal of Health Psychology|volume=16|issue=8|pages=576–586|doi= 10.1177/1359105314559619|pmid=25476575|hdl=10138/224473}}</ref><ref name="Schonfeld">{{cite journal|authors=Schonfeld, I.S., & Bianchi, R.|year=2016|title=Burnout and depression: Two entities or one|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|volume= 72|issue=1|pages=22–37|doi=10.1002/jclp.22229|pmid=26451877}}</ref> In a study that directly compared depressive symptoms in burned out workers and clinically depressed patients, no diagnostically significant differences were found between the two groups; burned out workers reported as many depressive symptoms as clinically depressed patients.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Boffy | first2 = C. | last3 = Hingray | first3 = C. | last4 = Truchot | first4 = D. | last5 = Laurent | first5 = E. | year = 2013 | title = Comparative symptomatology of burnout and depression | url = | journal = Journal of Health Psychology | volume = 18 | issue = 6| pages = 782–787 | doi=10.1177/1359105313481079| pmid = 23520355 }}</ref> Moreover, a study by Bianchi, Schonfeld, and Laurent (2014) showed that about 90% of workers with full-blown burnout meet diagnostic criteria for depression.<ref name="Bianchi, R. 2014"/> The view that burnout is a form of depression has found support in several recent studies.<ref name = "Ahola"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="Hintsa-et-al"/><ref name="Schonfeld"/><ref>{{cite journal|authors=Wurm, W., Vogel, K., Holl, A., Ebner, C., Bayer, D., Mörkl, S., & ... Hofmann, P. |year=2016|title= Depression-burnout overlap in physicians|journal= PLOS ONE|volume= 11|issue= e0149913|pages=e0149913|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0149913|pmid=26930395|pmc=4773131}}</ref>
==Risk factors== Evidence suggests that the etiology of burnout is multifactorial, with dispositional factors playing an important, long-overlooked role.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Alarcon|first1 = G.|last2 = Eschleman|first2 = K. J.|last3 = Bowling|first3 = N. A.|year = 2009|title = Relationships between personality variables and burnout: A meta-analysis|url = |journal = Work & Stress|volume = 23|issue = 3|pages = 244–263|doi = 10.1080/02678370903282600}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Swider|first1 = B. W.|last2 = Zimmerman|first2 = R. D.|year = 2010|title = Born to burnout: A meta-analytic path model of personality, job burnout, and work outcomes|url = |journal = Journal of Vocational Behavior|volume = 76|issue = 3|pages = 487–506|doi = 10.1016/j.jvb.2010.01.003}}</ref> Cognitive dispositional factors implicated in depression have also been found to be implicated in burnout.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., & Schonfeld, I.S.|year=2016|title=Burnout is associated with a depressive cognitive style|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume= 100|pages= 1–5|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2016.01.008}}</ref> One cause of burnout includes [[stressor]]s that a person is unable to cope with fully. Occupational burnout often develops slowly and may not be recognized until it has become severe. When one's expectations about a job and its reality differ, burnout can begin.
Burnout is thought to occur when a mismatch is present between the nature of the job and the person doing the job. A common indication of this mismatch is work overload, which sometimes involves a worker who survives a round of layoffs, but after the layoffs the worker finds that he or she is doing too much with too few resources. Overload may occur in the context of downsizing, which often does not narrow an organization's goals, but requires fewer employees to meet those goals.<ref name="Maslach972">{{cite book|authors=Maslach, C. & Leiter, M.P.|title=The Truth About Burnout: How Organizations Cause Personal Stress and What to Do About It|location=New York|publisher=Jossey-Bass|year= 1997}}</ref>
The [[job demands-resources model]] has implications for burnout, as measured by the Oldenburg Burnout Inventory (OLBI). Physical and psychological job demands were concurrently associated with the exhaustion, as measured by the OLBI.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Demerouti|first1=Evangelia|last2=Bakker|first2=Arnold B.|last3=Nachreiner|first3=Friedhelm|last4=Schaufeli|first4=Wilmar B.|title=The job demands-resources model of burnout.|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=2001|volume=86|issue=3|pages=499–512|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.86.3.499}}</ref> Lack of job resources was associated with the disengagement component of the OLBI.
Maslach, Schaufeli and Leiter identified six risk factors for burnout: mismatch in workload, mismatch in control, lack of appropriate awards, loss of a sense of positive connection with others in the workplace, perceived lack of fairness, and conflict between values.<ref name="Maslach01">{{cite journal|last1 = Maslach|first1 = C.|last2 = Schaufeli|first2 = W. B.|last3 = Leiter|first3 = M. P.|editor = S. T. Fiske |editor2=D. L. Schacter |editor3=C. Zahn-Waxler|year = 2001|title = Job burnout|journal = Annual Review of Psychology|volume = 52|pages = 397–422|doi = 10.1146/annurev.psych.52.1.397|pmid = 11148311}}</ref>
Burnout is supposed to be a work-specific syndrome. However, this restrictive view of burnout's scope has been shown to be groundless.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Truchot | first2 = D. | last3 = Laurent | first3 = E. | last4 = Brisson | first4 = R. | last5 = Schonfeld | first5 = I. S. | year = 2014 | title = Is burnout solely job-related? A critical comment | url = | journal = Scandinavian Journal of Psychology | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 357–361 | doi=10.1111/sjop.12119| pmid = 24749783 }}</ref> In other words, burnout could apply to nonwork roles such as that of caregiver or student.
==Effects== Some research indicates that burnout is associated with reduced [[job performance]], coronary [[heart disease]],<ref>{{cite journal|author=Toker, S., Melamed, S., Berliner, S., Zeltser, D., & Shapira, I.|year=2012|title=Burnout and risk of coronary heart disease: a prospective study of 8838 employees|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|volume= 74|issue=8|pages=840–847|doi=10.1097/PSY.0b013e31826c3174|pmid=23006431}}</ref> and [[mental health]] problems (although note the abovementioned research that suggests it is a depressive syndrome, e.g., Ahola et al., 2005<ref name = "Ahola"/>). Chronic burnout is also associated with cognitive impairments such as [[memory]] and [[attention]].<ref>{{cite journal|last = Sandstrom|first = A|author2 = Rhodin IN|author3 = Lundberg M|author4 = Olsson T|author5 = Nyberg L.|title = Impaired cognitive performance in patients with chronic burnout sysndrome.|journal = Biological Psychology|year = 2005|volume = 69|issue = 3|pages = 271–279|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301051104001553|accessdate = December 5, 2012|doi = 10.1016/j.biopsycho.2004.08.003|pmid = 15925030}}</ref> Occupational burnout is also associated with absences, time missed from work, and thoughts of quitting.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal | last1 = Elliott | first1 = T. | last2 = Shewchuk | first2 = R. | last3 = Hagglund | first3 = K. | last4 = Rybarczyk | first4 = B. | last5 = Harkins | first5 = S. | year = 1996 | title = Occupational burnout, tolerance for stress, and coping among nurses in rehabilitation units | url = | journal = Rehabilitation Psychology | volume = 41 | issue = 4| pages = 267–284 | doi=10.1037/0090-5550.41.4.267}}</ref>
==Treatment and prevention==
=== At the individual level === It is difficult to treat the three symptoms of exhaustion, cynicism, and inefficacy, as they react to the same preventive or treatment activities in different ways.<ref name="Hätinen-2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Hätinen | first1 = M. | last2 = Kinnunen | first2 = U. | last3 = Pekkonen | first3 = M. | last4 = Kalimo | first4 = R. | year = 2007 | title = Comparing two burnout interventions: Perceived job control mediates decreases in burnout | url = | journal = International Journal of Stress Management | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 227–248 | doi=10.1037/1072-5245.14.3.227}}</ref> Exhaustion is more easily treated than cynicism and professional inefficacy, which tend to be more resistant to treatment. Research shows that intervention actually may worsen the professional efficacy of one who originally had low professional efficacy.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Van Dierendonck | first1 = D. | last2 = Schaufeli | first2 = W. B. | last3 = Buunk | first3 = B. P. | year = 1998 | title = The evaluation of an individual burnout intervention program: The role of inequity and social support | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Psychology | volume = 83 | issue = 3| pages = 392–407 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.83.3.392}}</ref>
For the purpose of preventing occupational burnout, various stress management interventions have been shown to help improve employee health and well-being in the workplace and lower stress levels. Training employees in ways to manage stress in the workplace have also proven effective in prevention of burnout.<ref>{{cite book|author=William D. McLaurine|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uRU3tG29VfUC&lpg=PA92&dq=job%20burnout%20prevention&pg=PA92#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= A correlational study of job burnout and organizational commitment among correctional officers|publisher= Capella University. School of Psychology|page= 92|isbn=9780549438144}}</ref> One study suggest that social-cognitive processes such as [[organizational commitment|commitment]] to work, [[self-efficacy]], learned resourcefulness and [[hope]] may insulate individuals from experiencing occupational burnout.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Increased [[Job control (workplace)|job control]] is another intervention shown to help counteract exhaustion and [[cynicism (contemporary)|cynicism]] in the workplace.<ref name="Hätinen-2007" />
Burnout prevention programs have traditionally focused on [[cognitive-behavioral therapy]] (CBT), [[cognitive restructuring]], didactic [[stress management]], and relaxation. CBT, [[relaxation technique]]s (including physical techniques and mental techniques), and schedule changes are the best-supported techniques for reducing and preventing burnout in a health-care specific setting. Combining both organizational and individual level activities may be the most beneficial approach to reduce symptoms. A Cochrane review reported that evidence for the efficacy of CBT in healthcare workers is of low quality, indicating that it is no better than alternative interventions.<ref name="ReferenceD"/>
Employee rehabilitation is a tertiary preventive intervention which means the strategies used in rehabilitation are meant to alleviate, as well as prevent, burnout symptoms.<ref name="Hätinen-2007" /> Such rehabilitation of the working population includes multidisciplinary activities with the intent of maintaining and improving employees' working ability and ensuring a supply of skilled and capable labor in society.
Additional prevention methods include: starting the day with a relaxing ritual; adopting healthy eating, exercising, and sleeping habits; setting boundaries; taking breaks from technology; nourishing one's creative side, and learning how to manage stress.<ref name="pat">{{cite web |url=http://health.usnews.com/health-care/for-better/articles/2017-02-27/politically-active-4-tips-for-incorporating-self-care |title=Politically Active? 4 Tips for Incorporating Self-Care, US News |date=27 February 2017 |work=US News |accessdate=5 March 2017 }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA2">{{cite web|authors=Smith, M., Segal, R., & Segal, J.|year=2014|title=Stress Symptoms, Signs, & Causes: The Effects of Stress Overload and What You Can Do About It|accessdate=31 March 2014|url=http://www.helpguide.org/mental/stress_signs.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927114835/http://www.helpguide.org/mental/stress_signs.htm|archivedate=27 September 2014}}</ref>
=== At the organizational level === While individuals can [[Coping (psychology)|cope]] with the symptoms of burnout, the only way to truly prevent burnout is through a combination of organizational change and education for the individual.<ref name="Maslach972"/>
Maslach and Leiter postulated that burnout occurs when there is a disconnection between the organization and the individual with regard to what they called the six areas of work life: workload, control, reward, community, fairness, and values.<ref name="Maslach01"/> Resolving these discrepancies requires integrated action on the part of both the individual and the organization.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on workload means assuring adequate resources to meet demands as well as [[Work–life balance|work/life balances]] that encourage employees to revitalize their energy.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on values means clear organizational values to which employees can feel committed.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on community means supportive leadership and relationships with colleagues rather than discord.<ref name="Maslach01" />
One approach for addressing these discrepancies focuses specifically on the fairness area. In one study employees met weekly to discuss and attempt to resolve perceived inequities in their job.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = van Dierendonck|first1 = D.|last2 = Schaufeli|first2 = W. B.|last3 = Buunk|first3 = B. P.|year = 1998|title = The evaluation of an individual burnout intervention program: the role of in- equity and social support|url = |journal = J. Appl. Psychol.|volume = 83|issue = 3|pages = 392–407|doi = 10.1037/0021-9010.83.3.392}}</ref> The intervention was associated with decreases in exhaustion over time but not cynicism or inefficacy, suggesting that a broader approach is required.<ref name="Maslach01" />

'''Reductive art''' is a term to describe an artistic style or an aesthetic, rather than an art movement. Movements and other terms associated with reductive art include [[Minimal art]], [[ABC art]], anti-illusionism, cool art, rejective art,<ref>Green, Jonathan. ''Newspeak: a Dictionary of Jargon'', p.155. London : Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1984.</ref> [[Bauhaus]] aesthetic, work that emphasizes clarity, simplification, reduced means, reduction of form, streamlined composition, primary shapes, and restricted color.<ref>Maximalist Painting: "More is More", Essay: "A Reaction to Reductive Art" by Rachel Thornton, Florida State University Museum of Art. p 5,6.</ref> It is also characterized by the use of plain-spoken materials, precise craftsmanship and intellectual rigor.<ref>''[[MINUS SPACE]]: The Art of Reduction'', [[P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center|P.S.1]] Newspaper, Fall / Winter 2008, p. 2.</ref>

{{about|the 1890s footballer|the 1910s and 1920s footballer|Robert Buchanan (footballer, born 1887)}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Robert Buchanan | image = | fullname = Robert John Buchanan | height = | birth_date = {{birth date|1867|11|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], Scotland | death_date = {{death year and age|1909|1867}} | death_place = [[Southwark]], [[London]], England | position = [[Striker (association football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Johnstone F.C.|Johnstone]] | years1 = 1887–1892 | clubs1 = [[Abercorn F.C.|Abercorn]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 1892 | clubs2 = [[Sunderland Albion F.C.|Sunderland Albion]] | caps2 = | goals2 = | years3 = 1892–1894 | clubs3 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps3 = 40 | goals3 = 12 | years4 = 1894–1896 | clubs4 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]] | caps4 = 42 | goals4 = 16 | years5 = 1896–1899 | clubs5 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps5 = 41 | goals5 = 21 | years6 = 1899–???? | clubs6 = [[Sheppey United F.C.|Sheppey United]] | caps6 = | goals6 = | nationalyears1 = 1891 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 1 }} '''Robert John Buchanan''' (22 November 1867 – 1909)<ref name = FATS>{{cite book|last1=Chalk|first1=Gary|last2=Holley|first2=Duncan|last3=Bull|first3=David|title=All the Saints: A Complete Players' Who's Who of Southampton FC|year=2013|location=Southampton|publisher=Hagiology Publishing|isbn=978-0-9926-8640-6|p=31}}</ref> was a Scottish international [[association football|footballer]], who played as a [[Striker (association football)|forward]] in the 1890s.
==Playing career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Edinburgh]],<ref name = FATS/> he started his career as a youth player with [[Johnstone F.C.|Johnstone]] before joining [[Abercorn F.C.|Abercorn]] in 1887.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/player_details.cfm?playerid=113239&CFID=3151048&CFTOKEN=14606560|title=Scottish Football Association Player profile| publisher=www.scottishfa.co.uk | accessdate=16 December 2007}}</ref> Whilst on the books of Abercorn, he made his solitary international appearance for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] on 21 March 1891 scoring in a 4–3 victory over [[Wales national football team|Wales]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.londonhearts.com/scotland/games/18910321.html|title=Wales 3 Scotland 4| publisher=www.londonhearts.com| accessdate=16 December 2007}}</ref>
He then moved to England to join the short-lived [[Sunderland Albion F.C.|Sunderland Albion]].<ref name = FATS/>
===Burnley=== After Sunderland Albion disbanded in May 1892, he transferred to [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], playing in the [[Football League First Division]]. In [[1892–93 in English football#First Division|his first season]] he was top scorer (jointly with [[Billy Bowes]]) with eight goals from 22 appearances, helping Burnley to finish in sixth place, their highest league finish to date. The following season, Buchanan was less successful in front of goal with only four goals from his 18 appearances, but Burnley finished the season one place higher in [[1893–94 in English football#First Division|the league table]].
===Woolwich Arsenal=== In September 1894 he moved to join [[Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]], for [[1894–95 in English football#Second Division|1894–95]], their second season in the [[Football League Second Division]]. Playing alongside [[Peter Mortimer (footballer)|Peter Mortimer]] and [[Patrick O'Brien (footballer, born 1875)|Paddy O'Brien]], he contributed nine goals from his 25 appearances, which included a goal on his debut, in Arsenal's 4–2 win over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 29 September 1894. The [[1895-96 in English football|following season]] he made 17 appearances with seven goals, switching from [[centre forward]] to [[inside left]]. In total he scored 16 goals in 44 league and cup appearances for Arsenal.<ref>[http://www.arsenal.com/history/profiles/86/bob-buchanan Arsenal career summary]</ref>
===Southampton=== He moved to the south coast in the summer of 1896 to join [[Southern Football League|Southern League]] team [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton St. Mary's]]. The [[Southampton]] public took to him immediately and his "''never-give-up''" attitude earned him the nickname "''Death or Glory Bob''".<ref name = FATS/><ref name = ABC>{{cite book | title=The Alphabet of the Saints|last= Holley |first= Duncan |author2=Chalk, Gary | publisher= ACL & Polar Publishing | year=1992| isbn=0-9514862-3-3|pages=52–53 }}</ref> In his first season with the "Saints" he was ever-present, scoring eleven league goals as Southampton took the Southern League title for the first time. He scored a [[hat trick]] in his second appearance, a 6–1 victory over [[Sheppey United F.C.|Sheppey United]] on 26 September 1896. He also helped Southampton reach Round 2 of the [[FA Cup]] for the first time, where they went out to [[Manchester United F.C.|Newton Heath]] after a replay.<ref>{{cite book | title=Saints – A complete record|last= Chalk|first= Gary|author2=Holley, Duncan | publisher= Breedon Books| year=1987| isbn= 0-907969-22-4|pages=20–21}}</ref>
The following season, he was [[Southampton F.C. seasons|top-scorer]] with ten league and six FA Cup goals as the Saints again took the Southern League championship. Saints also had a superb run in the FA Cup reaching the [[FA Cup Semi-finals|semi final]] where they went out in a replay 2–0 to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. In the cup run he scored "''unlikely goals''"<ref name = "ABC"/> against [[Leicester Fosse F.C.|Leicester Fosse]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
Although he remained with Southampton for the [[1898–99 in English football|1898–98 season]], he only played twice. After 57 appearances for the Saints with 33 goals, he moved back to south-east London to join [[Sheppey United F.C.|Sheppey United]].<ref name = FATS/>
==Later life== On retiring from the game, he settled in [[Sheerness]], where he worked as an engine-fitter and died in [[Southwark]] in early 1909.<ref name = FATS/>
==Honours== ;Southampton * [[Southern Football League|Southern League]] championship: [[Southern Football League 1896-97|1896–97]] & [[Southern Football League 1897-98|1897–98]]
